description:
Location: 24th / Folsom, deep in the mission and convenient to walk from the BART. 
 Ambience: Scandinavian minimalist. Outdoor patio lures sun loving people and it's general clean. Music isn't too loud and the layout of the tables provide seating for solo travellers, table for 2 as well as one couch to slouch on.
: F&B: offering small toasts, cookies and pastries. The teas are good, chai are not that strong. Still have to test out their coffee. Coffee beans provided by Ritual.
 WIFI: sometimes slow, outlets are plenty.
author: Marzia D.

description:
Maximally pretentious.  Crazy expensive.  I walked by dozens of times on my way to and from the BART and never entered.  

But I followed my friend inside once, and had to admit that Haus delivered everything you'd want or expect from a bougie coffee shop: the barista acted as though taking my order inconvenienced him, the coffee was 4 or 5 bucks, the coffee tasted really good, and the backyard area was pretty nice.
author: Christian J.

description:
expensive tea at $4.50 a pop and when I asked if I could have a mixture of 2 types of their loose leaf tea I was refused. The barista said that it was the owners specific policy that teas could not be mixed. 

Place is packed on the weekends and the wifi is not strong enough to support all the users without significant latency. 

Catch it in off hours for a pretty nice space to work but be prepared for unexpected rigidity from the owner / staff. 

(If the owner watches yelp reviews I would *love* to hear an explanation for the absurd no mixing policy on their very expensive tea)
author: Joel D.

description:
The ambiance and indoor and outdoor seating options in this cafe are quite cozy and work-friendly, so I'm a bit surprised that the ratings aren't higher for Haus.

I stop in here on my way in at least once a week when the weather is warm enough for their iced coffee.

I can't remember ever getting anything but iced coffee at Haus, but I've always had stellar and friendly baristas ringing me up. The iced coffee is not the best in the world (or I am possibly just not a fan of the Ritual Coffee Roaster beans that they use for it), as I found it a bit too "fruity" or to my possibly underdeveloped palette, sour. However, I do like grabbing coffee here out of convenience and to enjoy the brief, quaint atmosphere I have in it before going on with my daily obligations (it beats waiting awkwardly in a limited, crowded and cluttered space at Philz a couple of blocks away).

I would recommend Haus baristas to try and change up their iced coffee's beans blend, possibly to something more full-bodied, deeper, or nuttier/smokier in flavor!

A small situation happened today where I was rung up by an older barista who thought I ordered an iced latte and overcharged me for it. However, the second barista was kind enough to return the difference to me, but I ended up having them keep it for their continual amicable services.
author: Victoria W.

description: Decent coffee, polite staff and more importantly, great place to work! On warm days, the back patio is perfect. Restroom and tap water available.
author: Shaw L.

description:
Great spot for work! Hipster cafe with outdoor seating.

- Fast internet and down-to-earth staff, always cool to have a casual conversation. 

- Especially love their toasts (spread on artisan breads) for $4 & home-baked cookies. So far I've tried Sprouted Rye, Walnut Levain, Sprouted heat Pullman, and they are all very delicious. Freshly baked with a tasty texture. I usually get the honey spread, or almond butter & berry jam. It's both healthy & filling. Always satisfied.

- The overall ambiance is cozy, space often occupied by working professionals. Sleek interiors, great lighting, aesthetic wood chairs outdoors. 

- The only downside is this place's seats are often filled. Even if there are empty seats, they are very close to one another. So space-wise it's not ideal. 

- It's about a 7-10 minute walk from the 24th mission bart. Pretty convenient location. Doesn't open very late. As someone who doesn't live in the mission, I drop by only when I'm around.
author: Jess W.

description:
Nomadis cafe in Mission.

Love this environment, friendly staffs. When you come inside, you can see so many nomadic workers with their Mac Book PC. Coffee and some bread, cookies tastes great! And remarkable point of this cafe, you'll use outside terrace. This area has fresh air, and you can be refresh.
author: Shun Y.

description:
Large, comfortable space with a beautiful outdoor space in the back. Prices are a tad bit high at $4.50 for hot tea and $4.00 for iced tea.

Cookies are $3 each. I tried the popcorn + chocolate cookie.. it was odd, not sure what the popcorn was supposed to add but it tasted a bit stale.
author: Elvi T.

description:
Simple and cozy place for coffee and chat. Was visiting from Vegas. 

 Patio on the back makes the ambience balance.
author: Smart T.

description:
They have great coffee and cookies! 

Patio on the back is cozy and spacious. Great for an afternoon coffee break!
author: Kseniya M.

description:
One of my favorite cafes to work at with excellent WiFi, tons of power outlets, good focus music, and most of the patrons are also zoned into reading or work. 

The Experience: The space is fairly large, but it's usually packed with patrons working on their laptops, especially on the weekdays. While this creates a fantastic work environment, it's not the best venue for chatting or hanging out with friends. You're expected to be churning work -- which is why I can always trust a visit to Haus to fire up my productivity. 

The coffee, tea, and pastries leave something to be desired. There are offerings of a variety of jams and butters on bread, but the price is steep for a slice of dry bread with some jam slapped onto one side. Maybe the price makes sense -- I'm sure price isn't a consideration and becomes relatively inelastic when the starved techie who's been zoned into code for 6 hours straight takes a breath from her laptop and stumbles towards the counter. 

"Give me 5 breads please. Any jam." This is me at least once a week. I usually rationalize to myself that the $40 is well worth the hours of high-throughput productivity. 

Tips:
-- The Chai Latte is the only redeeming item on the menu. It's very light and fluffy yet with a full-bodied spice profile.
author: Jessica M.

description: The place is great. Lightning, and seats are good. Except the bathroom is disturbingly disgusting. Like really disgusting. The cringing type. Ugh
author: Kat P.

description: This is a solid spot in Mission if you're looking for hip minimalist vibes. Haus Coffee serves up a thick and satisfying French Press from Ritual Roasters as it's standard brew fare. French press as the default? A first in my cup. I love going here with a good novel, an empty notebook, or alone with my sad thoughts. Just kidding. I'm generally a happy guy. I haven't tried the espresso drinks but I'm sure they're good - the latte art is industry standard from a glance. There's a sunny patio area with reclining chairs and viney walls, perfect for some summertime avocado vibes.
author: Alton Z.

description:
Have been looking for a good studying spot for a while. Without a doubt, this is my favorite place.

There is an outside portion of the coffee shop! With tables and chairs outside, people can enjoy the sun while enjoying a beverage and studying.

I got the cappuccino and the jasmine green tea. Both great! The teapots are also very cool.

There is free WiFi here, as well as lots and lots of outlets. Ideal working spot for sure.
author: Do P.

description: Great place to sit and do work. It's pretty quiet and there are lots of outlets available. The barista was extremely friendly as well! He left me a laptop charger when I forgot mine. 10/10 service + great coffee. Definitely will be back in the future :)
author: Leslie L.

description: Close to Gents barbershop which is a goto place for my husband, tried the macchiato here and it was spot on. Lot of seating - tables not so clean
author: Anju J.

description:
A sleek, modern coffee shop conveniently located on 24th Street in the Mission, Haus serves dependable coffee drinks and a limited selection of baked goods.

Although power ports are somewhat limited, the key draw is the venue, as there's plenty of space to sit and work. The outdoor patio might be somewhat alluring, but bear in mind that it often fills up with dryer fumes from the adjoining residences. Even then, the interior is gorgeously done and has a fair amount of seating. 

Quite the nice independent venue that's worth patronizing. Again, thanks Yelpers for a great find!
author: Vincent L.

description: Excellent croissant. I went there on a Sunday morning to get some work done. Their playlist was fabulous; I shazam(ed) a few songs. Coffee is not outstanding but does the job. The space was super clean.
author: Audrey B.

description: The coffee is pretty ok. For $4.50 that's pretty disappointing. The coffee shop itself is cute and a great environment to study and work. However, this prices for everything are pretty wild considering the quality isn't there. The outdoor space is pretty cute I must say and I do appreciate the hours the place is opened and the fact they have WiFi. If you're looking for a space to work and aren't looking for the best of drinks, come here.
author: Kalani R.

description:
While this wouldn't be my first stop for coffee and pastries, it is definitely one of my top picks for a study spot. Came by on a Wednesday afternoon in search of a study spot. This place had quite a few people but there were plenty of seats left and most of them were within reach of an outlet. There's a cute outdoor patio, some bench seating, and single person tables throughout the cafe. I love that most of the tables get natural light too.

The employees here (a younger woman and an older man) were both very friendly. I got an ice coffee which was a bit pricy but it was quite good. Very acidic but light and most importantly it kept me awake. Wifi is consistent (dropped once but otherwise very fast). They also offer some sweet & savory toast options if you get hungry or there's quite a few food options within walking distance.

Overall, Haus Coffee is a great a study spot and I'll definitely be back.
author: Vivian C.

description: Great space to work and sip on a creamy double macchiato. I really enjoyed sitting at the backyard patio daydreaming about my future cafe
author: Tiffany C.

description: Good coffee and service albeit tiny expensive cups but one of the best places to go to get your wifi on. Its fast and they have tons of seating and outlets.
author: Sean G.

description:
Outdoor seating rocks

Great vibe with wooden tables and a fire place

Food is expensive and limited but this is one of my favorite places to do work and relax
author: Sam K.

description: Lots of tables both inside and outdoors. Coffee is okay, could be better.
author: Kimberly H.

description: It's your typical SF coffee spot. Hipsters and Macbooks everywhere. A bit too quiet for my taste and the outdoor are gets a bit too hot with the direct sunlight. Coffee (covfefe?) itself was good and it's a nice spot to kick it for a while. Seems like a spot to get work done, pretty much a library from how quiet it was.
author: Rohit S.

description: First time here - hard to convince myself to do so with Philz right across the street. Came here to work with my husband out on their patio. Opted to go espresso route vs coffee because I feared I'd only be disappointed w the coffee, and espresso seems like a safer choice for places where you're uncertain as to the quality of beverages. As expected "ok" but not great. Husband's French press was "ok" as well. If looking for a great venue to hang out and work this place is great, but don't come here exclusively for the coffee. Many better options available.
author: Rachael S.

description: The place is sleek and cool enough to make me feel uncomfortable. It's got that New Mission vibe to let you know they want you to buy the expensive coffee and then not linger too long. My laptop had a good charge which was necessary because there are no outlets there if you want to work, and I sat and wrote for a spell in their shadow-filled patio in back. Not sure why anyone would go here over Philz, but it certainly has a crowd that fills it up.
author: David A R.

description: A super warm day calls for some iced coffee. I happened to be on the same street so decided to check out this place. When I walked in, I was surprised at how quiet it was. Like, really really quiet. I get the impression that people come here to work more than chill with friends so keep that in mind if you're looking for the latter. I got an iced almond milk latte which was really good. Since I was not planning to work with everyone else, I decided to sit outside in the sun. People were working out there, too, but it seemed less intimidating somehow, haha. Plus, I would get to enjoy the nice weather! Not too crowded on a Saturday afternoon so that seems to be a good time to visit. I would come back if I'm in the area but probably only if I'm alone so I don't disturb anyone with conversation.
author: Pooja C.

description: Sublime combination of coffee shop and coworking space. The inside has the clean lines and minimalistic appeal of an Apple Store.
author: A T.

description:
Aesthetic is nice, walking in is nice, employee is not. Friend and I got all settled in to work and then not even 15 minutes in the brunette employee with glasses approached us and asked us if we were going to buy anything because "usually people that use the wifi here, buy something." We felt unwelcomed and just left. Obviously if I have the wifi already connected, I was a previous customer who had bought something there. I guess they don't care about valuing guests? Anyhow, that made us not want to buy anything. Sucks too cause last time that girl was nice but maybe sales revenue was low today. Not enough gentrifiers to go around. 
Last time I was here I was doing work for 3 hours and then ordered something. Not a single worker approached me.
author: Jade J.

description:
I was looking for a quiet place to work for about an hour and half right before noon. Haus Coffee is as quiet as your local library! All the seats inside were taken with people working away. Seriously, pin drop silence. Score!

I took my almond croissant, sat on the patio, and dialed into a meeting. The wifi was pretty consistent except for a few times where there was a pause or delay. Not bad though, especially for the hour. 

I like this space. I can't speak for the coffee (although I noticed it was Ritual), as I had just filled up on Philz down the street. The almond croissant was a bit dry with minimal filling, but had a good overall texture. 

The patio is breezy and warm. I'd come back, especially to work. There's plenty of outlets.

Zen in the midst of chaos.
author: Shereen A.

description: I've never been here, but I hate everything about San Francisco now that it's populated by rich techie creeps. So there.
author: Al B.

description:
Drinks were good. Outside patio was very cute, I would have sat outside if it wasn't raining.

Street parking only, metered spots. Didn't have trouble finding parking, surprisingly! Maybe because it was a weekday in the late morning?

Went to go do some work with friends, didn't have issues finding seats. Hard to find an outlet. Wifi sucked and we weren't able to get much work done. Had to leave early. Won't be back.

Overall, great place to hang out and catch up with friends though!
author: Wendy T.

description:
Macbook Air and some hipster quality (mustache, hat, bracelet, tattoo, etc.) required for entry. Just kidding, although if you look around, this does seem largely like a spot for hipsters or techies to get work done.

The coffee is solid, the tea is great. But the real draw is the beautiful work environment. The place is beautifully lit, with plentiful seating and desk space. It's a reliable study spot in the Mission.
author: Tim X.

description:
this is one of my favorite cafes to get work done!!!!! and here's a few reasons why: 

+ wifi: idk whats up with SF but it is SO hard to find places with wifi! (granted this one is a bitttt spotty, it does get the job done!)
+ open area outside and inside: i love working out in the patio on a nice spring day. they have great umbrellas outside, and it's easy to feel calm and relaxed. i've always managed to snag a seat and not feel overwhelming cramped. 
+ quiet working environment: this is DEFINITELY the place to go if you need to get stuff done and want minimal distractions
+ open late: again, one of the few coffee shops open past 6pm on a sunday. great place to just camp out and get some stuff done!!!!
+ basa seafood next door: LOOOOLOLOLOL i love basa (see review there) and it's awesome to hop next door after you get a caffeine fix for a quick lunch break!

oh ya, the coffee is great too. but i'm throwing down the 5 stars because this cafe has helped me out so much in terms of my studying needs ^_^Y
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Stand up and be that killer Tuesday macchiato! Haus has delivered on this promise to me for years. Typically you will see this spot jammed with geeks and their loyal laptops geeeeks! But for my purposes caffeine to-go they are perfect!

Oh yes and those geeks are the head phone geeks their eyes dart around as they sit alone in their online universe in a full room
author: Lisa S.

description: One of the few non-franchise coffee shops with wifi. Which is why 90% of the patrons are there to work, so expect to be quiet and not go to catch-up with a friend. Their limited pastires are okay. They do have a stellar patio, if you want to catch some Mission sun.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
The coffee here is great and the baristas always do a fine latte art. You have the choice of sitting inside or in their backyard -- great on sunny days. Oh, and they also have free wifi.  

My only qualm is that this place gets awfully quiet since everyone's usually working on their laptops with headphones on, so if you're looking to chat away with a friend you'd literally be the only person talking in the room.
author: Gouthaman K.

description:
Not sure why this place isn't rated higher. This is a great place for working as long as you have laptop battery (only a few plugs inside)! They've got plenty of seating indoors (tables and a couch) and outdoors. Sitting in their outdoor patio is a little urban oasis - really great lighting without getting too warm. I particularly like the wood panels for walls in the outdoor patio. 

Broad selection of coffee and loose leaf tea. Loose leaf tea comes in a pot which is great!
author: Inga C.

description: Can get LOUD: It takes luck to be able to get work done here. Sometimes you get a barista who loves to blast her music while everyone is wearing headphones trying to get work done. I asked her very nicely to turn it down just a little bit. She got really offended as if I'm hating on her music. Gave me the look and refused to talk to me again. It's unfortunate given that the coffee is pretty good.
author: Lars S.

description:
This is the most ideal work cafe I have come utilized in San Francisco.
Lots of tables, great beverages, and a clean comfortable environment.
If your trying to get out and get some work done this is the spot you are looking for.
author: Dustin L.

description:
Needed to find a new study place with a chill and quiet environment. Found this little place on yelp and was intrigued by the ambience so decided to check out. 

Bright, clean, warming environment was my first impression as I walked in. The scene was pretty relaxed with almost everyone on their macs/pcs doing work. Seating was a bit scarce, but luckily my friend and I scored a nice table along the wall. Outlets are not a problem as the place provides with an ample amount which was great! Noise was not to bad I would say a 4-5 out of 10. Music got a bit loud at times depending on what they played, but it was also due to a couple gentlemen talking a whole bunch right beside us pretty loud about random things. Literally felt like I was in the conversation with how loud they were taking to each other. 

Despite that I was able to get a lot of work done in the 2 1/2 hrs I was there. Got there around 6:30pm. (One of their busiest times)  

Ordered a macchiato and my friend ordered one of their teas which was also pretty good. Forgot which one he got. 

Overall, I would say its a great, cozy environment to study and get a quick fix of caffeine. Bring headphones if you get distracted easily by other conversations. Definitely, coming back to get some more work done.
author: Sunny P.

description:
Haus Coffee is the coffee joint to go to in the Mission if you need to get some work done or study. The cafe itself is very minimalist and generally quiet. It is filled with patrons with headphones in and laptops out, typing away and being productive. Most people take their conversations to the patio in the back equipped with tables and lots of greenery. 

The coffee at Haus is okay. Nothing special. The menu is pretty basic like most hipsterish coffee shops these days. The $4.60 latte I had definitely wasn't the smoothest I've ever had, nor did it have latte art for me to snap a pic of and post to instagram, but it was decent. The toast here is pretty good! For $3 you can get a small, but filling slice of yummy bread topped with various things from goat cheese and honey to avocado. Great brain fuel.

As a whole, I'm a fan of Haus. I would definitely come here if I wanted to get some serious work done. It has lots of seating, little distractions, solid wifi, plenty of outlets, and a bathroom. That said, if I was just looking to grab coffee with a friend and chat I would definitely opt for a different cafe with better coffee, and louder atmosphere.
author: Umeet S.

description:
Beautiful, minimalist space with ample seating in store as well as on the patio out back. When I went, only one person was working so I was slow to get served but didn't mind much since they were very friendly and I was staying for a bit. There was a consistent flow of people coming in for drinks, but most seemed to stick around in the store. Probably not the best place to catch up with a friend (maybe go to Philz across the street instead), but wonderful to catch up on reading, journaling, or some work. 

Plentiful outlets. Wifi. Very clean. Surprisingly quiet/calm space. Notably young crowd.
author: Rosa Y.

description: The place is kind of small and coffee is not the best. It's okay if you are lucky enough to get yourself a place on a couch, but otherwise not the best place to hang out.
author: Anastasija V.

description:
Imagine a place that combines the uninspired interior design of a Mac store with mediocre coffee and top that off with the shame of being surrounded by white techies and vampire esq real estate developers and business people and you'll have pictured Haus. 
I have avoided this place for years but I had to use the bathroom while doing laundry next door so I sucked it up and went into this yuppie embarrassment. I ordered an iced Americano and it was $4 which is more than most places, but what ever. But then I got served a 70 second shot, despite watching them weigh several shots before mine. I was nice but not creepy,I tipped I dunno what I did to get the this guy sucks shot but I did.
author: John Wednesday L.

description: Pretty expensive as you would expect. But they made a damn good almond milk latte. Seems like a good place to get work done, everyone was on a laptop or phone doing so. I met some friends here in the morning and we almost felt uncomfortable chatting. We decided to sit in their sweet outdoor patio with benches, tables, chairs, and umbrellas. Not the coziest place.
author: Ruby H.

description:
I come here often. Its a good place to get work done. People are anti-social and stare at each all day but it a library-like environment so fine by me. I can see how the staring can get to some though. Its contagious btw.

The capps here are usually good. Sometimes they are burnt. The place seems to have a hard time getting employees. Not surprising given SF rents. 

One butch girl there really should not be working any sort of service position. Her mind-blowing lack of people skills can get under your skin. I was in there once when the place was leaking and as soon as I walked in she started yelling at me. I was quite taken by it but Im a chill person and have seen it all at this point so I just looked past it and ordered my drink. She then started yelling at me again telling me to hurry up ... this was after I ordered. Girls got some psychological issues. So prepare yourself. 

Other than the personality disorders here, I like the vibe here since I am a developer. Its one of the better places in SF to get work done during the day. The owner seems like a very cool guy. So I continue to come and look past some of the people behind the counter. Not, all of them. Just that 10% that ruins it for the rest.
author: H K.

description:
A great neighborhood place. I love the outdoor seating in the back. Perfect on a sunny day.

Great coffee!
author: Frank T.

description: This is such a neighborhood gem. Great outdoor space, WiFi, nice staff, low key. My favorite spot to work out of in the neighborhood on a weekend.
author: Rose J.

description:
This place gave me the most interesting first impression of a cafe. Came here on a Tuesday night and there were quite a few people. But it was literally dead silent--no music playing, everyone was either on a laptop or reading a book, and you could literally hear the footsteps of the barista behind the counter. I get it when you have those quiet cafes that are good for studying or working, but this place was so silent it was eery. When we ordered, I almost feel like we had to whisper our order. Fortunately, I think the staff picked up on the awkwardness and turned on some music. You could immediately see the mood lighten up a little bit.

Besides the interesting impression, we tried a mocha and a hot chocolate. Both drinks were excellent and rich. They serve their drinks in mugs for a very cozy feeling. I feel like if I had to find a place to do some uninterrupted reading, I would think of this place. Plus there is a lot of space--I'm sure that during the daytime they have their outdoor seating open; kind of wish they actually had some lamps out there or something.
author: Ethan J.

description: I was excited to discover this place a few weeks ago. It has a nice atmosphere and the lattes are pretty good. Had a cookie one day and it was a little dry. Unfortunately, just got a chai latte here and I would not recommend, pretty undrinkable.
author: Claire M.

description:
I feel like there is an unspoken rule about Haus where people are strictly there to get work done.

The tables are so tight nit that it's hard to feel uncomfortable sitting next to the person that is motivating you to finish the book that you've been meaning to finish. It is so quiet that even whispers would get people to give you looks. I believe the baristas play music only because they can't stand the silence. The ambiance is light and organic. I can't help but walk around to the back patio to see how much of the cafe is made by the staff. Speaking of the back patio, it's even quieter than the inside since the music only drifts out the door.

Besides the ambiance, the staff is really nice and the coffee is good. I recently had their mocha and I thought it had the perfect level of sweetness. It was very foamy and the coffee art made me really happy. If you need me, I will be here starting on my next book.
author: Linda K.

description: Haus Coffee is one of several cafes located on 24th Street in this part of the Mission, and I think what sets this place apart is the ambience.  There are a lot of wooden tables and huge windows that allow a lot of natural sunlight, and there is also an outdoor patio if you are looking for fresh air while you get your caffeine fix.  There's usual a large number of people working there when I pass by, but I've never found Haus to be too crowded or noisy when I step in.  I've been happy with their espresso-based drinks, and the employees are amiable.
author: Keith H.

description: Great place to get some work done. Fairly quiet, light background music.
author: Allan B.

description: Hause coffee is the kind of place you walk into and immediately know is the place to be. Looking through the window you see a minimalst wooden theme that is pleasing to the eye. Often packed to the brim with people pecking away on their computers or having conversations about anything from books to their next big idea, the shop gives off the vibe of a trendy coffee fueled business meeting. Upon taking my first sip of coffee the place lost a bit of its charm as I realized the meticulously desigined interior is, in a large way, compensating for the subpar coffee. I personally would rather drink a great coffee in a place with rickety tables than stuggle to finish a cup of joe in the trendy spot.
author: Chris V.

description:
Great little coffee place caddy corner to Philz.
Really nice ambiance and great iced coffee! Pleasantly surprised to see the outdoor working space in the back. It feels like your friend's backyard and during a day when it was cloudy everywhere else in the Mission, there was plenty of sunshine here!

Only negatives are 1) its so silent to the point where you almost feel guilty having a conversation (my colleague and i were there to grab a coffee and catch up. nobody gave us dirty looks or anything but i definitely felt a bit self-conscious at times as we were the only 2 ppl talking and 2) bathroom is decently clean but smells like the powell bart station :( please give it a scrub down.

$3.50 each for iced coffee and iced tea. Bit high but you're getting very nice ambiance and great coffee.
author: Yin H.

description:
This place offers a more spacious, comfier environment than Philz up the street. The coffee is pretty good, the service is friendly, the line is never long, and they offer free wifi. 

It would be great if they offered some more food options. Right now it seems limited to cookies and a few croissants. I've come here a few times and often hankered after something with a little more substance. 

Some might also find the atmosphere a little sterile. Most everyone inside is heads-down on the laptop. In fact, it seems oddly quiet for a coffee shop. It attracts a lot of serious looking individuals with macbooks and a pile of homework. Friends looking for a lengthy chat, or groups of any kind might find it a whole lot less awkward to take their coffees on a walk around the block. 

What really gives this place the 4 stars is the outdoor space! Haus a clean back patio with plenty of seating and lots of sun. It's a great place to enjoy an iced coffee. Even on weekends, there is space enough to spread out with a board game and a couple of friends (seems chatting on the patio is not looked at so unfavorably). I'm surprised the secret isn't out yet...
author: Brittany B.

description: My go to when Philz is too busy or I'm heads down and need to work. Good tea and coffee. A lot of tables indoors but the best thing about this place is the outdoor patio. It has walls so it's not too windy and is a great place to enjoy the outdoors.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Haus, arguably, has one of the best environments for studying/working. I often need a good workplace (+coffee) in the city when I decide to "work from home". This caffeine spot does an excellent job of fulfilling that need.
The coffee and tea are good. I wish they had more power outlets to charge one's electronic devices.
author: Samridh C.

description:
I love this place comme like paradis maybe? Its just super chill and chai tea is delicous. 

They play really good music which is nice because a lot of cafe's can be hella bunk and obnoxious with their pop music blasting.  They play stuff like boards of canada and honestly some other stuff i don't even know but just good. Reliably good. breads & cream cheese with jam is my favorite.  

Wifi a dark bathroom / outside patio / outlets/ chairs oh la la its just too good to be true 

Also, there is a panederia nearby or places to get your haircut so you know its good
author: Gabriella C.

description: Most computer/wifi friendly cafe in SF! The natural sunlight through the large windows is a big plus too. Owner is a very nice guy.
author: Hamrez S.

description:
Fancy pants hipster coffee shop in south Mission

First: what does the name mean? Is "Haus" German for "House"? Who knows? The plot thickens...

Second: the decor is very, very nice for a coffee shop in that area. It feels like a furniture/design store inside.

Third: as you will notice, most of the clientele is also dressed fairly hipster-ish

Jokes aside, the place is a solid coffee shop, with fast wifi, lots of seats, nice lighting, courteous waitstaff, and solid quality drinks (I only ordered the tea, but it was served in a nice clean teapot).

Would definitely come back, if I manage to find a space! It's usually quite crowded.
author: Henry L.

description: Haus Coffee is conveniently located on 24th street in the Mission District. It's a decent coffee house which is located right beside a laundromat, which IMO is its biggest selling point. I used to visit this place every Sunday while my clothes were in the washer but there's a Philz a minute away from this place and the latter makes much better coffee. Would recommend only if you're looking for a really quiet place to do some work or stay away from some of the hipsters that may show up at Philz.
author: Gaurav K.

description: the place is nice and so is the atmosphere, however the girl who was working there was quite rude. my friend and i set up to do our work and not even 15 minutes in, she approaches us & basically kicks us out for not purchasing something when we had just gotten there; it's not like we werent going to we very well could have until she confronted with unnecessary rudeness
author: Carla E.

description: What can I say? This place was just MADE for techie/ body snatchers who have invaded the Mission. Devoid of warmth or humanity. Intriguing. Fruity coffee that is orangish brown. Nice patio. Dry pastries. But, who needs moisture ,flavor or character in a muffin when you're a hostile alien in human disguise merely miming the act of eating because that's what humanoids do? Because that's the main type of customer who comes here. I guess they gotta go somewhere to connect to their devices. Might as well be all in one spot. The staff here are lovely, however. I truly empathize with them.
author: michelle b.

description: As a physical structure, this is a lovely coffee shop, with nice open spaces and good natural lighting and charming art and a generally pleasant aesthetic.  It also has a lovely patio area and its employees are consistently excellent.  Its critical flaw is its clientele.  As the day proceeds they trickle in, and every single person is hip-seeming and of a certain socioeconomic class.  They settle into their seat at one of the many tables and lock their bespectacled gaze with monomaniacal focus on their (inevitably) MacBook, until by peak hours Haus might as well be occupied by a clone army.  I have a travel typewriter that I was gifted and which I never use (because typewriters are very impractical) but I want to take it to Haus and clickety-clack away on its keys just to annoy the other patrons for being so boring.
author: Kyle W.

description:
Yeah, no.

The coffee here is subpar. However, the space is amazing. Anyone who gave this place 4-5 stars is probably a developer, a business owner, or someone who doesn't genuinely enjoy coffee because they burned the latte and the whole thing was like a block of foam. It felt more like having the only coffee available when I am in Europe versus a quaint, boutique coffee shop in the Mission.

There are basically forty businesses here because seriously everyone here is on a macbook of some sort working on some app or other. The outdoor space in the back is great, but they definitely cannot make coffee to save their lives. Pass.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Great space, decent cappuccino. They serve Ritual beans, the coffee is mediocre, not worth detouring just for it when there's other coffeeshops in the area. However, if you care about hanging around and the ambiance. It's a much comfier, less sterile environment than Ritual. The indoor area is wooden, warm, and filled with people so I went to the also quiet(er) back patio area which has lots of tables.

Everyone seems quiet and heads down in their own world. Not a great place for hanging out and chit chatting because of that. It's a bit far from where I live but I'd come here again to work.
author: Truc N.

description: Stumbled across this sleek, clean, fresh coffee shop. They do not have drip coffee, but it is still flavorful and delicious. The atmosphere is what really stole the show. All light colored wood from floor to ceiling, gentle music, and an outdoor area. The price is the going rate. Excellent spot that I will for sure recommend to others if not take them there myself.
author: Bryn C.

description:
A comfortable coffee shop in the mission with wifi, outlets and takes cards! It's like finding the holy grail. It's not insanely loud, as others have pointed out. It seems almost like a co-working space. Back patio is very nice. Wish there was more than one umbrella. (hint hint Haus management!) 

HOT TIP: the wifi password is ***surreptitious***
author: Sarah K.

description:
As a freelance designer, I'm always on the lookout for good coffee shops to put your head down and work for long periods of time.

This place is the ticket - laid back vibe with a very productive atmosphere. Quiet, minimal, decent coffee, free + consistent WiFi, good amount of outlets, well lit, back patio or indoor seating, and open late-ish. No frills, good shit!
author: Emily S.

description: Great outside patio area and atmosphere. The ice coffee here is no bueno, and wifi was reallyyy bad - so I had to move to Philz across the street. Service was also meh, and I couldn't hear what the barista was whispering.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Ambience. Space. Vibing.

Absolutely beautiful space, with gorgeous outdoor area, literally why 4 stars. "Alt" vibe, relatively quiet. 

Fantastic for working, most people here are usually jotting in pads or typing in macbooks.  

Coffee is meh (for SF), good some days and pretty expensive. 

In the end, it's the perfect place to zone in on whatever you need to get done, and I come by often to do just that.
author: M B.

description: Lovely comfortable environment, but the person on the counter was unnecessarily rude, she ruined it for us. It was 9am in the morning. Hope they work on their service more.
author: Aldarsaikhan T.

description: I love to come work at this coffee shop. It is really cute, and the architecture and design is wooden and simple making it a perfect working environment. The tables are small so they great for single use or two people. The coffee is good too! A huge plus: they have a patio!
author: Victoria L.

description:
I always have a lovely experience here. If you want to sit down in a trendy environment to work on something or meet with a friend for coffee this place is great. Very clean and lots of natural light.  The outdoor area is peaceful and beautiful. 

The only reason I give it 4 stars is because the menu is pretty limited on drinks and especially, food. However, they do give you a whole pot of tea when you order it to drink there. The people are friendly and easy going. 

Definitely recommend this place to everyone!
author: Estela D.

description:
I'd have to say that this place is actually my favorite Coffee stop in  the city of San Francisco.

Why? You might ask.
1. Great minimalistic design
2.Good Coffee at a decent price. The iced coffe/house brew costs around $2.50 which is  definitely do-able in this city of "high quality" coffee and coffee snobs.
3. Wifi and quiet/spacious. Meaning it's a great place to stop by and get some work done. I've been able to find a spot and work here for upwards of 2-3 hours, which is pretty rare to in the city in my experience.
4. Parking. Because of it's location in the mission district, I've found that parking at this place is a lot easier than at most other coffee joints in the city which is great.
5. Tacos. Another great part of being in the Mission is that you're no more than 5 minutes walk away from any number of delicious taco places.

Getting work done and tacos. What else is there to talk about?!
author: Andrew T.

description:
Love this place.  Hipster-ish latte joint, with a comfortable feel.  Big tables, free wifi, and the male barista is so friendly, smiley, and nice.  You'll find me here, most days of the week, getting stuff done.  My comfort zone!  :)   

Hesitated to write a review..  because don't want place to get too crowded..
author: Dana C.

description:
Great customer service. It was only one barista taking order and making drinks and she continued to work through the long line and was very nice to everyone. The almond croissant was delicious. Latte was good. Plenty of outlets and I did not have to fight for tables. I did go there early morning and it was peaceful and quiet with music playing in the background. Overall this place is spacious and I got some homework done! 

I only wish they had more pastries, more drink options, and possibly sandwiches. But it's okay :)
author: Karen J.

description:
Nice little cafe. 
I got Chai and it was the best Chai I've ever had. Super smooth and spicy. Service was nice and prompt. 
It's a bit expensive,  but the Internet connection was fast and it's an overall good spot to study at. 
I wish they would have more food options. They only had 3 cookies and 2 muffins when i was there.
author: Juliana B.

description:
I have been hesitant to review Haus Coffee because I am afraid the secret will get out!

Haus Coffee is one of my favorite locations in San Francisco to get work done. The atmosphere is usually quiet, there is a beautiful and peaceful patio out back, and they offer free wifi. If you are looking for a quiet place to be productive, Haus Coffee should be on your list!

As for drinks, they serve Ritual coffee which is my go to caffeinated beverage and Mighty Leaf Ginger Twist tea which is my go to decaffeinated option. 

Their only selection of pastries is a variety of chocolate chip cookies. However, it is what it is: a fabulous nook with great drinks. 

To be honest, there are not a lot of places in the Mission with a comparable atmosphere. I have always had positive experiences at Haus and my only wish is that I lived closer so that I could spend more time there!
author: Sophia A.

description: A nice place to get homework done. Don't bring any snobby expectations towards their coffee - they DO use Ritual - but you won't get the same quality of espresso shots and knowledge that you would find at an actual Ritual location, I suppose. That being said, my espresso was well balanced without any off putting salty flavors. The real magic of Haus is the environment. Oriented towards a getting work done kinda vibe, Haus offers plenty of outlets, fast internet, and a usually low sound volume atmosphere. I've never felt like I am taking up a seat at this place. 5 stars ;)
author: Anthony P.

description: I live around the corner and was once a regular here.  The coffee is thick and rich, some of the best around, but they've jacked the prices up by nearly a buck in like the last six months.  I like the sparse feel and don't mind that the place looks like the birth scene in the Matrix with all of us locked into our Macs, but with that and the fact that the staff always seems revolving, now, I just can't go there anymore.  A bummer.  I guess $4 is the market rate for an iced tea in the area but I'd rather just write at home.
author: Eric M.

description: Is this a conceptual art piece around the question of how little effort can be put into a cafe and keep the lights on? What the hell, owners? Slow. Bad tasting coffee. Slow. Dead-eyed baristas. You can't be bothered to get a toaster oven to warm up your freakin croissants? That you buy from wherever. So quiet. So... Cold. I think I just died.
author: steve m.

description:
If you look at my profile you might notice that all my reviews are either really good or really bad. That's because I only review places that I really like or really don't like. Haus is one of the places that I really like. I've only come here one time so far (after traveling from another coffee place I didn't review) and even as I was sitting there on the sunny patio, I got excited thinking about the next time I was gonna come back. I almost feel bad for rating it so high because now everyone is gonna flock to this place (solely based on my review lol).

The ambience is basically the opposite of philz that is right across the street. It's laid back, quiet, and peaceful with calm music. There's only one barista and the seating was very organized. The place was about half full when I came and had plenty of outlets. They also give you your tea in a cute teapot! I got the green tea with jasmine. It was great (:

Highly recommend this place for anyone looking for a calm place to do work (yea they have wifi).
author: Angela W.

description:
Four Barrel, Blue Bottle and Philz seem to dominate the SF coffee scene. Here at Haus, they carry Ritual and Dela Paz beans. The decor is simple but modern: exposed maple beams, concrete floors and track lighting. 

Laptop campers are welcome here with the outlets against the wall. There's a nice patio towards the back, although it was raining when I came. 

Butterlove bakery supplies their goods. I was in the mood for something savory so I tried their veggie galette filled with mushrooms, asparagus, onions and goat cheese. It was incredibly flaky and super flavorful. Not bad price for $3. My body was deliciously caffeinated with a good cup of cafe Americano. 

For you die hard Philz fans, it's only a block away. But if you're looking for a space to do work while enjoying (almost) equally good coffee, Haus doesn't disappoint.
author: Janice C.

description: Great place to study and enjoy caffeine with a treat. The staff is very professional and attentive.
author: Dee Q.

description:
I am so totally impressed by this place.

Stumbled across this place by accident when I was looking for a quiet place to do work (I had forgotten my headphones too!), and didn't feel like braving the crowds at Philz next door. Luckily I stumbled into this gem.

There were virtually no people there at 8:30am on a Thursday. The space is super nice, well lit, with spacious wooden tables, high ceilings, and plentiful plugs. Wifi is fast and there's even an outdoor patio!

Best of all, I could get tons of work done because it was so peaceful. The only downside to it being so quiet is that I could hear every word as the 28495628th guy tried to flirt with the barista.

One star off because the coffee is not super quality, and there are not really many food options.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Outstanding place to do your work, but save your money on the coffee.

Let's get the bad news out of the way: I could barely swallow the dirty chai latte, and my friend hardly touched her latte/coffee-tinted milk. To be fair, I'm not the biggest fan of chai, but there was barely any flavor, so next time I'll go for a mocha or normal latte. I also spent $6.50 on that chai latte, which is a travesty by itself. The drink options are limited, so only order standard drinks here.

The ambiance for working, on the other hand, can't be beat. Although the benches are pretty uncomfortable if you sit in them for more than an hour, the black couches near the outside patio(!) provide great cushioning if you want to lounge while working. And because this place isn't super packed, you'll definitely be able to grab a spot on the sofa if your heart or butt so desire. The larger tables can fit a maximum of four people, while the small tables are typically taken up by the lone Macbook Air.

I'll give mad props to whoever plays the music, too. It isn't too loud that you can't focus, but it's pretty great to listen to Smashing Pumpkins lightly in the background sometimes.

Unfortunately, even 90s rock can't make up for the coffee here. Come here for work, and work only, or at least walk down the street to other coffee and food places before heading here so you won't be sorely disappointed.
author: Kat P.

description:
Great space for working. Tons of space, lots of outlets and power strips, very bright, plus there's a back patio.

The internet is fast, and there's two connections. The barristas were friendly.

They also have iced Americanos. This ain't Austin, so I can't say they're the most amazing iced coffees ever, but I'm not here for the coffee. I love the hell out of coffee, but there's a crap ton of great coffee in San Francisco, spaces like this for working are harder to come by. And we got two of those for $5. That's a pretty cheap cost to work in a space like this for a few hours. 

The non-stop Biggie was awesome as well. Great atmosphere.

To top it all off, Humphrey's Slocombe and El Giro Gallo are right around the block. 

One drawback is I didn't see a water jug, so bright my own next time.
author: Shawn S.

description: Second time in 2 days that I've walked in at 8:30, waited patiently in line, then waited while they made other drinks, then 15 minutes later told they were out of plain old drip coffee. This place always takes for ever and doesn't even have the basics on hand. It's too big a space to only staff one person at a time, especially during the morning rush.
author: Sunny Y.

description:
Absolutely adore this little hole in the wall cafe! 

I feel like the atmosphere is what makes me want to keep coming back here. I love the aesthetic of the whole place, how accessible it is since it's in the mission and fairly close to bart, and the fact that I could be here in the day time or night time and I could genuinely stay productive.  I love the for here tea pots that they provide you when you order your drinks - it really adds to the overall aesthetic of Haus. 

I also love how this is a space where people can genuinely get work done, chat with a friend, sit outside and enjoy some sunlight and have a photo op, etc. The coffee at this place is also pretty decent with a good price point as well.  I'd much rather be supporting local businesses like this one than going to a coffee shop thats run by a corporation now a days and this place has just become one of my favorites to chill at.
author: Kai S.

description: Let me start by saying that I was absolutely blown away by the atmosphere of this place and if this cafe was based on looks, I would give it five stars. Now that that's out of the way though let me get to the nitty gritty. After soaking in the awesome furniture and cricket quiet atmosphere I was greeted by a less than enthused female barista with buzz cut who rolled her eyes at my girlfriend and I after I had told her that we needed to look at the menu before ordering (there was no one behind us). After deciding on an iced coffee for me, and a limeade for my gf I tried to get the baristas attention. I noticed however that she was buttering some toast (or so it appeared) and gave her some time to finish what she was doing. When ordering she seemed unhappy to be there and like she would rather be elsewhere or maybe just left alone.   When she was preparing our drinks I whispered to her inquiring about why it was so quiet (a question I thought harmless) and she snapped back, rolling her eyes once more the way I would imagine a teenage girl would saying that people were working, which to her point seemed to be true. The iced coffee was a delight but the limeade was just some whole foods lime juice and selzter. So all in all I am not only extremely upset by the rude and snooty barista, but also the drinks. Who in there right mind would pay $3.5 for something store bought? It makes no sense. So next time I'm in the mission Haus Is NOT getting my business.
author: Sam L.

description:
It's great coffee, you can really taste the acidity in their plain black coffee, so you know they roasted their beans well.
Reasonably priced, too.
Nice place to get work done.
Really nice outdoor seating.
My few gripes with the place is:
    I couldn't help, but feel like I'm not wanted there. Maybe I came at a bad time, but their baristas seem a bit grumpy with a forced smile. 
    I somewhat don't recommend chatting in there, or at least not too loudly, because the people there are there to work. Well... "work."

Also, the place is somewhat hard to find, because they have only 1 sign that says "HAUS" in big, red letters. And they don't carry business cards. 

But, all in all, it's a nice place to work, but not for a quick cup of coffee or to catch up with friends.
author: Alan L.

description:
Though I love Philz, which is right around the corner, I would easily come here if I needed to get some work done. I came in ready to get work done today and found a seat easily since they have several tables. For those of you who make cafes their niches like I do, they have several extension cords so your laptops won't be without juice even if you're here for more than a couple hours.

Interior is really nice and clean. Simple space with minimal decor. Wooden features, artwork along the walls, and ample, natural lighting. They also have plenty of seats in their patio, which is just as nice as inside. Though, I'm not too sure how many outlets there are, if any, outside.

I ordered their iced black tea, limeade, and bran muffin and all were pretty good! Black tea wasn't too strong, and the limeade wasn't too sweet--as with the bran muffin. Everything was just right. I have yet to try their coffee. But will definitely be back for it.
author: Kristine N.

description: The coffee is pretty good and the vibe of this place was nice until the blonde barista started eye-balling me like I was gonna steal something. If you're a person of color, be warned. The female barista here will give you a racially charged "what are you doing here" kind of a glare if you're not the typical white privileged techie. Aside from that, the coffee is great and the pastries are good. Just didn't like the experience I had with that particular Barista.
author: Mandy R.

description: I'm surprised it's not rated more highly than 3.5 stars, as it is the perfect hang space, especially for working.  The music is always good but never gets in the way of focusing on some quiet laptop type work.  Staff always super friendly in a nice quiet way and there's a lovely back area where, on nice days, is more than spacious enough for people to do their work and hang back there.  Not a great deal in the way of eats but I think the emphasis is that this is a remote work location that makes you feel welcome in a number of ways and serves up perfectly good teas and coffees.
author: Evan K.

description:
Pretty good. The back courtyard is kind of a mess but welcome none the less.

Flys in the pastry box were funny but not appetizing.

Lots of people talking loud on their cell phones in the back courtyard.

Still like the place.
author: Thatcher H.

description:
Ambiance: If you wana get shit done, Haus Coffee is your place. Come here with your laptop/ notebook and you'll be good to go. It's laid back, quiet, and peaceful with calm music playing in the background.

Basically, you can work here peacefully without being disturbed. Think: Library voices.

Seats: There's tons of seats inside with outlets. They also have an outdoor patio with plenty of open space. If you enjoy summer time SF weather, check this place out with a good book.

Coffee: They serve Ritual coffee, while the coffee is nothing spectacular, they've got FAST WIFI!
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Great place to work. Very serene environment. Cool music that is not obtrusive at all. Great coffee. 
Oh and beautiful outdoor seating too!
author: Alireza R.

description:
Haus Coffee reminds me of Local 123 on San Pablo in Berkeley: it has the good vibe and a very attractive back patio.  Haus is visually stunning, and it's obviously a great place to work, study or meet with friends.  Walking in the door and leaving 24th Street transports you to another world.

That's the good news.  The bad news is that I found my macchiato quite bitter.  I don't know whether the culprit is the choice of beans (which is what I guess) or the barista's lack of skill (nah!).

My drink wasn't a deal-breaker.  I'll be back for another try.
author: Kenneth R.

description: PLEASE STOP THE AWFUL MUSIC.  I like everything about HAUS, but I cannot for the life of me understand why they play the music they do- if you can even call it that. It ranges from a burping sound over a satanic beat, to the random clanging of a mental health patient.  The coffee, decor and backyard are all tastefully prepared, yet the music makes it impossible to get any work done or have a pleasant conversation.
author: Sasha D.

description: Meh coffee. Ok attention. Price on the high end. Enough better options nearby. Avoid.
author: Manny H.

description:
Coming upon Haus as you stroll on 24th in the Mission is a bit shocking. It's so serenely white (...in every sense of that word) that it feels like you're watching a scene from an Ingmar Bergman movie in the middle of a Telemundo novela. It's like you're watching Liv Ullmann whisper quietly about the disintegrating state of her marriage to a dour psychiatrist in a white turtleneck, while Gloria on "Modern Family" is banging on the door and yelling - "Hey, Leeev, you theenk in Colombia we treep over goats and we keel people in the street!... Do you know how offensive that eez? Like we're Peruvians!"

Got the picture? Well, Jamie W. and I came here only after seeing the endless line at Humphry Slocombe at 8:30PM. Haus doesn't serve ice cream, not at all. No, they brew beans from Ritual Roasters and De La Paz, so it's good stuff. But I have to tell you that the place lacks... how do I put it? Oh yeah... character. It's quiet in here because it seems to target hipster laptoppers. I think the noise I was making while sipping my $2.50 Chai Latte was about as loud as it got in here. No small-talk conversation. That wouldn't be appropriate in a Bergman film. I think the owners should have Death walk by in a black cloak and holding a sickle just to remind people they're really in urban guerilla mode in the Mission.

COFFEE - 3 stars...warm, soothing but nothing spectacular
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...like an IKEA that was ransacked
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...very coolish and frigid
TOTAL - 3 stars...very Bergmanesque
author: Ed U.

description:
Likes: the patio area, location, it's quiet, good amount of seating, they have loose leaf tea and the new employee is speedy, friendly and personable (the other person was like a zombie :P)
Dislikes: lack of food options, ever changing prices, bitter coffee, dirty bathroom - sometimes it's smelly but it has improved a bit and it is the most expensive place I've ever bought coffee/tea from in my life!
author: Angela V.

description:
great vibe, great playlist, cute backyard patio area with tables for those perfect California days :) The indoor decor is simple and clean, the music is the perfect volume, and parking can be relatively easy to find on the weekends. It's also a convenient 2-block walk from the 24th Street Bart station! It's a mellow place without too much in-your-face personality for those mellow days we all have.

good for studying/reading or even just relaxing with a friend. Make sure your laptop charger is lengthy if you come with your laptop. WIfi is reliable and not glitchy, and there is no credit card minimum.  

tasty pastries and treats are served in addition to a fun assortment of coffees and teas for a delightful combo of mid-day munchies and caffeine pick-me-up.
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I came across this coffee shop when I was exploring the Mission District. The coffee and expresso are decent, but I wouldn't go raving to your coffee snob friends about it. The ambiance is what makes this place special. The design is clean and minimalistic with wooden furniture and fixtures. The lighting is excellent. It's quiet and serene. There's also a gorgeous patio in the back if you desire some fresh air with your cup of joe. 

Come to Haus if you need your caffiene fix AND want to get some major work done!
author: Steven P.

description:
Great place to study if you like silence and you don't care about the occasional bum that comes in, sits down for a few minutes and then exits. 

This is the most silent coffee shop I've ever been to. Which is A+ in my books because I love silence. Plus, the coffee and tea is fantastic! 

It's right across the street from Philz Coffee and a great neighborhood juice bar. Woooooo.
author: Lauren L.

description: If you want to feel like you're in a library while in the midst of bustling 24th street in the mission, come here - just don't talk..... Main reason for a mediocre rating is because my mediocre cup of tea (read: hot water with a generic tea bag) cost me a whopping $4. They don't even have stevia as a sweetener. Really? Pro: sit out back on the patio. It's quite charming.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Haus coffee seems to have gone through quite some change over the years. They use to play House music most of the day and you'd feel a little more comfortable talking or working. You can stick around for hours here and have some great tea and coffee (and great peanut butter cookies). It was so quiet on our last visit we had to sit outside to feel comfortable breathing because of the mellowness inside. Still a good place to focus!
author: Thom And Vicky H.

description:
Haus is my go-to for when I need to get work done in a quiet, chill atmosphere that isn't my bedroom/kitchen. There isn't a lot of decor, which is great for focusing. I dig the simplicity of it. Most people who go there will be working, too - so it's a good vibe to get stuff done. 

The internet was easy to connect to, which is always a plus. The barista that has been there my last few visits is super friendly and sweet.

During one of my first visits, a different barista was working and I asked if any of the pastries had nuts (I just developed a nut allergy a few years ago. So sad.)

He was perfectly honest and recommended to not get any of them since they may have touched utensils/kitchen supplies that have handled nuts. I appreciated his honesty; he could have easily made something up and tried to sell me one of them. Plus, I'd be pretty bummed if I died from it.

All in all, highly recommended for coffee-drinking remote/freelance workers.
author: Kirsten N.

description: Very quiet, great place to study or get some work done. Free wifi. There are literally power strips in certain corners. Maybe not aesthetically pleasing but efficient. Very nice outdoor patio, nice ambience. Minimal menu. I got the iced tea $3.50, nothing special but refreshing. Altogether I'd come back, sure.
author: Najeemah W.

description:
Do you think Haus Coffee would be cool with me bringing Philz from across the street over? I wanna drink my coffee and have space to drink it in too!

Although you can't order a mint mojito iced coffee here, Haus Coffee WINS the ambiance game. Everything is light wood and concrete and yet, despite being minimal, there is seating everywhere. Small table seating, leather couch seating, longer table seating, outdoor patio seating. Free wi-fi too, so GET SHIT DONE, this is the place.

I had a $3 12oz mug of brewed coffee (they use Ritual) and a $3 peanut butter cookie because cookies appear to be their only pastry items. It was really good though, I'm not complaining. 

I'll be back to get more shit done.
author: K M.

description: Great spot and good coffee but it is EXTREMELY quiet here. It's like a library (on the quietest floor)!! People would literally give you looks if you start talking..... I was whispering something to my friends and 3 people around me looked like they were about to kill me because they can't focus on their homework. Would love to come back with my friend but it sucks that we can't even have a conversation..... We're so scared to the point where we had to start texting each other lol. I love free-wifi but this place would make so much more money & more customers would come if they make it less like a library. Imagine each person would hog a table for a few hours and only pay $4 something for a drink.... I'm heading straight to Philz next time.
author: Ngoc L.

description:
My favorite get-shit done spot! 

Good coffee
killer organic granola bars
Plenty of places to charge laptop
Plenty of space
Quite
author: Hector M.

description:
Pretty much the best cafe in SF for me right now. I love this place. I love the coffee, the space, the baristas, and their taste in music. I even like the people who hang out here. Everyone's like, got shit to do. Polite. Mannerific. So I'm posting a Yelp review just to say thanks. 

I would say more, but, honestly, selfishly, I am not eager to see this place spoiled by crowds of leaf-in-mocha bearing trend-seekers. Go to Philz and discuss your Yoga class and wine-drinking. You and I will be happpier.
author: Neal P.

description: I would say this is one of the best, if not the best coffee shop to get work done at in San Francisco. Everyone is uber-focused here and so it's pretty quiet, although it's super crowded. I love the super-simple wooden decor and the coffee is pretty good. There's also a hole-in-the-wall sushi place next door that has delicious 6-dollar-sashimi which is an excuse I make to go here a lot.
author: Nina D.

description:
I've walked by this place probably a hundred times and never had extra time to stop in for a bit. It's got a rustic look that I really enjoy in coffee places... Maybe I'm a bit crazy for factoring my desire to have coffee in a place based on appearance alone, but oh well! My first impression when I walked in was that I had inadvertently stumbled into a library; the place is packed but silent, save for the light music in the background. Perhaps this place has a different feel on weekends (it's midday on a Tuesday), but this is obviously the place to go if you work remotely and need coffee, but also concentration. The young woman behind the counter is very pleasant, however I appear to have come too late in the day to get anything besides cookies. 
Despite the lack of sustenance, the coffee here is great.  If you've read any of my other reviews, you'll notice that I'm picky when I comes to 4 things, coffee, bagels, pizza, and burgers. Anyhow, Haus is reasonably priced and the black coffee is smooth and flavorful! I would certainly come back, but I think I'd need my laptop!
author: Jesse G.

description: Visited from Seattle. SF friends insisted that I try Phillz. It was disgusting. Walked across the street to Haus and had a completely different experience. A very fine ristretto indeed. (But I like coffee that tastes like, well, coffee.) The decor was very PNW, minimalist and earthy, with a gorgeous patio out back - I'd have stayed all day. Best of all? It was clean and had fast WiFi and my barista was friendly. A haven for a visiting Cascadian.
author: Candace F.

description:
(See pics) Review #1120. Germans are known to be orderly, structured, great organization and detailed in everything,  Haus has all of  these characters, clean and pleasant wood and white themed cafe set without round corners furniture. They offer different coffee beans (Ritual, De La Paz) and brew in a professional machine, My macchiato was very good..

Inside it's bright and apart the structured tables and chairs, there's a sofa at the back. Or if you feel like being outside, they have an outside area that you can get some fresh air with a few nice wooden tables and chairs as well.

You might wonder how to choose between Haus and Philz, being the fact that they are just a block from each other. Consider these as very different coffee houses, one is more hip and for chitchatting much ado about everything and the other serves more like some working space, one to get a big cup of truly artisan coffee with their own unique and individual beans while the other uses beans with more varied options of beans and roasting methods.

Service was nice and they also have some pastries if you want something to nibble on. Haven't tried those but will check it out on my next visit.
author: T L.

description:
They have plenty of outlets and free wifi here. They do sometimes have music a bit too loud so FYI for those like a more quiet ambiance

Limited choices on coffee, but it's okay because I usually only drink drip.

They have a nice patio area you can do work
author: Dorris W.

description: The outdoor patio is spacious, clean, and modern. The inside features outlets so it is a great place to work. However, I have to ding them a star for their utterly boring selection of snacks and pastries. The only thing to be had here is a good mocha or cup of coffee.
author: Damian E.

description:
This is my go-to coffee shop on 24th avenue. Why? Thanks for asking! Two reasons, actually: 

1) The baristas don't act like I'm covered in herpes. 

2) They have a huge outdoor patio for your morning shit talking. 

I like to play a game of "Count the Macs" when I come in. Today there were 18 Macs and one Thinkpad. Thinkpad guy was relegated to a small corner to sip his stupid fucking coffee in shame. I mean, how could he EVEN?!?

Also, they like to stump people with their WiFi passwords. Fortunately I won my 4th grade spelling bee and 'surreptitious' proved no match for my elementary school education. 

So why only four stars? Because every time I come here, the music - and I use that term loosely - sounds like a mash-up of trash can-drums, baby wails and yoga chants. 

Anyway, I'm babbling. Drink coffee? Duh. Of course you do. Come drink some here. Ignore the music, count the Macs and get the americano
author: Mel H.

description:
The best coffee shop on 24th street by far. Sugar Lumps is too dark, Philz is just gross, and the rest of the coffee is just garbage. Some lovely highlights include:

- Great lighting
- Good musical choices by staff
- Amazing back patio
- Damn good coffee

Also, the German woman that worked there before was a fantastic barista. She will be missed dearly.

Worthy of any morning commute.

P.S. They should get Square instead of that cash register. Would make tipping so much easier!!!
author: Joe P.

description:
Oh, Haus, you are who I have been looking for!  Discovering Haus Coffee in my neighborhood was like going on a date with a man who makes you laugh after nine dates with one who only want to talk about his cardigans and imported beard grooming wax.  FINALLY. 

 This is the coffee shop I have been looking for everywhere, to get things done.  This is the place to take yourself on a date with your lap top and be more productive than you have ever been in your life.  It is quiet and you can exist peacefully without  a ton of traffic.  There is a lovely back patio, as well, that is where you want to be on a sunny day.  

As I have to eat every couple of hours, lest my hangry-ness gets to me and I bite someone, I did check out their food options.  Although not extensive, I did try a chocolate chip cookie that was equal parts sea salt and chewiness and I think we are going steady now.
author: Allyson D.

description:
The worst coffee shop, ever. 

Got a cup of tea. There was stuff floating on the water on the top of the cup that looked like gasoline. I sipped it, and my throat started burning. I went back, and got a new cup. Poured more tea. Same outcome. So, I went back again, this time, just asked for some hot water poured into a paper cup. That's all I ended up having. The dude at the counter could care less about anything. Never even bothered to inquire into the issue. So I basically paid $4 for a cup of tap water.
author: Eater S.

description: I really like this place! They make good cappucinos. Today, I also got an almond croissant and it was amazing! The croissant was from Firebrand. Service is really friendly. I sat outside and the barista brought the cappucino out for me. I also found the patio chairs to be really comfortable because you can lean back at a slight angle, which is great when you're trying to read.
author: Mara C.

description: If you are finding a place for studying or working, you will like this place. Really silent and clean.
author: Mihwa S.

description:
No longer a secret, but every bit as divine. 

xoxo,
Gossip Girl
author: BroSauce J.

description: Great coffee and even better, they make a great Chai tea. The health bars they have are all fresh ingredients I believe gluten-free.  Really delicious... I had the coconut chocolate flavor. At the times I have gone the atmosphere has been calm and relaxed. Nice place to do some work while having a cup of coffee or some chai. The outside area is nice, as they have some canopy umbrellas for shade. It is a nice all patio setting with a quite atmosphere. Nice place to study or catch up on some work.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Perfect soy cappuccinos; Kombucha on tap!

The atmosphere is All City - best cafe in Seattle. It's perfect for a rainy day. 

My favorite part however, is the music, which is always very good.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I feel this is the best coffee shop in 24th street as well. Nice modern chic ambience. Awesome back patio. Like, awesome! chill soft music, and wide open spaces.

The only reason I took away a star is that the coffee is inconsistent. I've had great capps here (mostly), and milky light capps too.
author: Vinay K.

description:
From your existential nightmares. 

Ironic, isn't it? Seeing that most of the individuals here would love a good existential-nightmare (perhaps they are masochistic, I cannot tell entirely). See, I love Joy Division - I absolutely adore Ian Curtis, and New Order, and "Ice Age" may be one of my favorites. But do I really want to swallow myself in suicide and "Music to Harm Oneself To" when I am in a cafe? I leave my Bupropion at home for a reason...somebody really needs to give the person who picks coffee here a hug, and quick reference to psychological services. 

In any case, the coffee is mediocre, and whenever I would walk in here I felt as though I was in an Apple-sponsored adaptation of "Attack of the Clones." The walls crawl on you real quickly. And depending on the barista, you could get someone quite nice, as well as someone completely frightening and rude. The chai here tastes as though it was made with toilet water, and the coffee leaves much to desire for - but then again, Communist Cafe attracts its own generation of hipster, and a love for bland, terrible coffee.

Go home, Putin.
author: Peter S.

description:
Simplicity.  That was what initially caught my eye as I peered into the window of this seemingly Ikea-furnished cafe during the chaos of a crowded parade.  Almost everyone inside was equipped with a laptop and seemed completely engrossed in their work.  I knew immediately that I would fit right in.  I have since occupied a table at Haus a handful of times, whenever I had some project I really needed to buckle down on.  

At times, the music can be a little loud and distracting (and just plain odd) - nothing a pair of earplugs wouldn't remedy, though.  The people keep to themselves for the most part, however, I did have a fascinating conversation once with a Cal grad student who tried to explain the topic of his dissertation to me, bless his heart.  

The coffee and pastries are pretty good; I'm a sucker for the croissants.  They also have House Kombucha for $6.  The Wi-Fi is free and unlimited, and they have power extensions all around. :)

Parking is metered with a some two-hour zones a little further away.  Weekends work better for those of us driving in.
author: Carol Y.

description: Solidly crafted espresso drinks (for someone who normally drinks Blue Bottle, Sightglass, etc.)--far above most random Mission cafes. A lovely minimalist space and furniture, a great back patio, free wifi, plenty of room, and open until 9pm every day. Maybe the best work cafe in the Mission. I only wish it were open later; it would be my home away from home.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Nice staff with a back patio that is full of bees that I had to throw away the remainder of my sushi because they were all over it and I was about to get stung.
author: N A.

description:
Free wifi, hipster baristas, great coffee, outdoor patio, a lot of tables and outlets, other people on their macbook airs.

Great place to come and get some work done. It's pretty quiet so people do come here to work or talk quietly.
author: Andy J.

description:
I've been really curious about this place for a long time but I haven't had a chance to actually go in until a few weeks ago.

I needed to kill a little bit of time before meeting up with someone so I decided to go in and possibly get some reading done. 

I've passed by this cafe plenty of times so I've had glances of what it was like inside. Walking in, I still liked what I saw. Their choice in light colored wooded decor and simplistic style is clean and looks structured and organized. Seems like a good work environment! And it is. The only problem is that the seating is limited. 

They have seats and tables lining the walls and a lot of empty space in the middle. In some ways, I do like the empty space. It makes it look open and less chaotic. In other ways, I wish they had seating there just so there'd be more places to sit!

There is seating in the back where the outdoor patio is. The patio is really nice but it gets cold out even when the weather is nice. I had to sit out there because there weren't any seats inside. At first, I didn't mind so much because all I needed to do was read and I bought tea for myself...but after a while, the cold gets unbearable (and my tea got cold within minutes). It's not laptop friendly outside either. 

Overall, cool cafe! It's just hard to accommodate yourself if someone beats you to a seat!
author: Sofia R.

description: Pricey coffee ($3 - $4.50, and $0.75 extra for soy/almond) but it's a perfect working spot. Fast free WiFi and lots of clean, sturdy, light wood seating. There's a lovely outdoor area in the back and a smattering of electrical sockets available. Free street parking available around the block.
author: Christina J.

description:
I would give this place ZERO stars if I could. 

A close friend of mine used to work at Haus regularly on the weekends, sometimes patronizing them 3-4 times a week. On one of these occasions, the male barista with the glasses knocked over a large cup of tea onto her Macbook. I quickly ran to get paper towels but immediately noticed that the barista not only did not help but did not utter a single word of apology as he proceeded to help the customers in line.
