My friend was too preoccupied with trying to dry her saturated computer to notice. 5 minutes after this, the barista leaned over and told my friend he can give her a free cup of tea the next time she comes in but "next time don't put your cup there." Insult to injury ensued and we promptly left. 

After many in person exchanges with the manager, including providing him with contact information to follow up with us after consulting his lawyers, we have not heard from him once. My friend spent $820 to fix her damaged computer and even provided a copy of the invoice that clearly stated the reason for the damage was due to liquid spillage. 

It has now been several months with zero follow up or follow through from this establishment. While the coffee and pastries may be decent, I am a firm believer of voting with your dollars and Haus does not respect its customers or value their business. I will not be patronizing this establishment any longer.
author: John V.

description:
hm... I actually wanted to go to Philz coffee in the morning, but found the line was too long. So i gave this place a shot... a mistake.

This place is very open, high ceiling, lot natural light, and has a beautiful patio in the back. I thought it was a total score. But... i was wrong. I ordered a mocha. First... how could you not make me any leaves or patterns for my moacha. Especially, there was no lid given. Second, the mocha was so foamy and sweet ( I don't know if they use milk chocolate or whatever reason). Lastly, the mocha doesn't taste any shot in there, again, too sweet. 

If I ever, ever, come back here, i will probably order something else.
author: Evan L.

description: Philz coffee across the street is definitely better for actual drinks, however the coffee is passable and most importantly the space is fantastic for work! There are lots of tables, the space is quiet, and there is a lovely outdoor patio that has lots of shade. The seats are comfortable and not rickety. The whole place is filled with nice even light. Definitely the best Mission coffee shop I've been to for getting sh*t done.
author: Erin C.

description:
This is the first that I came here. I love this place.

The barista is nice and friendly. And everyone is polite and quiet. I absolutely is a big fan of the back patio. It is a good place to spend a few hours reading or getting some work done.

A few cons are: I'm not a big fan of the music which could be a little loud. I personally prefer something soft; occasionally there may be some people talking on the phone and they did not lower their voice. But it's not the coffee shop's fault. So I'm willing to ignore.

I will come back often.
author: Roxi W.

description:
Most drinks on the menu earn a solid 3 stars in my opinion.. You can honestly find better if you walk a block or two in either direction.  Across the street you'll find the iconic Philz or a few blocks in the opposite direction you have Bello coffee. 

Why 4 stars?.. Simple, it's one of the only coffee shops on 24th that has a cute patio in the back. If you're particularly fond sitting outside - this will likely be your most solid choice... 

Don't go if you're looking for the best cup of coffee or the freshest pastry. If you want a nice place to sit for a few hours with friends, it's not a bad option.
author: Tara K.

description:
Went to this new coffee shop in the Mission, close to 24th St Bart.  Nice, bright, & clean looking.

This is their drink menu:
Coffee $2/$2.5
Espresso $2
Americano $2
Macchiatto $2.5
Cappucino $3
Cafe Latte $3.5
Mocha $4
Ice Coffee $2.5
Tea $2
Chai $2.5
All shots double

They also have some pastries, bananas, & apples.

I wanted a cafe latte w/ coffee art but she told me she didn't know how to make it so I skipped it.  I got a Iced Cafe Latte $3.5 - I thought it was pretty strong so added Sue Bee honey, simple syrup, & some iced water.  mini shot glass sized iced cubes:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/-POyh7lkMmDY8PcOvjbgNA?select=NYIt_kZdd_ozrpb2a4M4jA

One unisex bathroom available.  Patio in the back w/ a table & chairs.  One leather sofa and a bunch of chairs & 1 long bench against a wall.

CASH ONLY now, next week the guy said for Credit Cards.
author: Ann L.

description:
Shangri-La might be fantasy, but this is a real life Laptopistan; the ultimate sanctuary for the coffeeshop-commuter. There are plenty of tables, concrete floors, an absolutely blissful electronic soundtrack, lots of natural lighting, impossibly photogenic clientele, free Wi-Fi and a good dispersion of power outlets too.

But its mythical aspects don't stop there; there is a touch of Grecian irony to this spot. The coffee isn't very good. They do OK espresso, but their press pot brew can be sludgy and oversteeped. This affront stings all the more, when you have the knowledge that goddamn Philz Coffee is across the street. You can literally watch people walking out of Philz with superior coffee from a window seat at Haus. It's kind of maddening, but the atmosphere is swell.

And I always drink tea there so I'm A-OK. Four stars.

Obligatory Title Pun: She's a brick, HAUS. 

Menu Readability: It's like on a music stand or something. 

Need to mention: They have a reallyn nice back patio.

What this place teaches me about myself: This truly is my circle of hell in Dante's inferno.
author: Vivek S.

description:
Holy Mac books! The vibe at this place is intense! You walk in and it's so quiet and everyone looks up. 
To be fair- I'm used to Philz.. But the line there was insane so I skipped over to Haus. Not quiet the same sort of scene. 
The decor is cool- reminds me of Four Barrel on Valencia. And the back patio is awesome!

I would recommend this place for an intimate coffee date or trying to get work done. Probably not a place for groups or boisterous types. 
Now- on the upside- the barista made a very impressively spicy chai. My friend noted that the espresso tasted sour but I didn't notice that. 
Also extra points for De la Paz coffee. 

Overall.. Interesting little coffee niche.
author: Sydney S.

description:
Came here just yesterday! Shared a mocha w/ the BF. was pleasantly surprised! Mild and sweet, smooth and creamy! and just right for the damp weather :) Our server was a very..quiet lady who didn't seem very friendly (no smiles), but also seemed skilled in pulling coffee.

Worthy to check out! :)
author: Christina C.

description: Love going here to study. The coffee is not that great but it's worth the study environment (plenty of tables and outlets) in my opinion. Kind of pricy (esp the food)
author: Linda Z.

description:
5 stars for their Americano!

Minus 1 star for the ambience. Ambience? What ambience? Every time I enter this place, all the tables are occupied! It's always a person plus MacBook per table. People don't talk in this coffeehouse. It's a sad, sad virtual world. I don't get it.
author: Misfit M.

description:
Calm atmosphere. Better than Philz. 

Great
-chai latte
-patio
-wifi

Could improve 
-ham and cheese sandwich would be even better warm
author: Tracy K.

description:
Get a cappuccino and a morning bun and you will be in heaven :)

Great place to hang / do some work / relax on the patio outside.
author: Joe M.

description: Quiet, good coffee. Yum. Outdoor patio.
author: Mel G.

description: While it is true that I find the coffee delicious and the atmosphere ingratiating at Haus, that's not what has prompted this review--although I have indeed availed myself of their tasty brew and solicitous service on dozens of occasions.  Before today, my last visit to Haus was in August, 2011.  Out of town since then, I waltz in today to have Roland, barista extraordinaire, not only greet me by name, but prepare for me, unbidden, my usual coffee drink, remembering how I idiosyncratically like it tweaked.  Does this kind of service make my coffee drink taste any better?  Not sure, but I've rarely enjoyed a cappuccino more.
author: David L.

description: Got lost in the mission looking for a coffee shop and a local recommended this place to me! The interior is beautiful and there's outdoor seating on the patio if you choose to stay (would recommend). They ran out of soy for my latte but we're able to substitute almond. Overall, very friendly people and a great atmosphere.
author: Sierra S.

description:
This is my go-to place to go to when I'm working from home. 

It's spacious, beautifully designed, has a clean restroom, is rarely full of people, has good wifi, and there's a lot of room for a laptop. Also, if the day is nice outside, you can work outside--they have tables in their courtyard as well. Dog friendly too, I think. It provides a great contrast to Philz Coffee just across the street--less people, more chill.

I usually go for a large plain black coffee here, paired with a massive chocolate chip cookie with sea salt. (Man, that cookie is good!)
author: Patricia L.

description:
Big love.

Peter Heller house classic: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=416iiYA7wsU

Big City house caffeine: Ritual or De La Paz (not sure which one) poured from a French press and accented with nonfat milk.

Last day of November it was almost warm enough to sit in the patio. Instead the free WiFi was enjoyed in the beautiful wood and art accented space.

Big love for all of this.
author: Jason B.

description: I like it. The wood furnishings and architecture totally caught my eye the very first time I passed by this place. I came back eventually and now I'm hooked. It's open relatively late for coffee shops in the area and free wifi is a priority for me. Credit card is accepted. Good coffee is in the haus. Drinks come in a nice big mug. The chai was frothy. There's a huge patio in the back with lots of seating and tables. The service is great, even though it's mostly just one person behind the counter at all times.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Good things: 
Friendly baristas! Solid coffee! Outdoor area! Natural decor (unfinished wood and concrete)!

Bad things:
Sterile! No atmosphere! 99% of patrons hunched over their laptops! What is this place doing in the Mission?

Outrageous:
A tiny, frantic mouse! Ironic considering the sterility of the place.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Being a philzvangelist I felt like I was betraying something by coming here. That said it's a really great space, especially if you have to get some work done. The good coffee, bright atmosphere and relative silence makes it one of those office coffee shops that you can probably be pretty productive at.
author: Misha T.

description:
Great place to meet or get work done. Beautiful modern wood interior and gorgeous back patio overlooked by a wall of ivy. The music is always great and the baristas always incredibly nice.

It's four stars in my mind because the coffee isn't as good as the ambience. The Ritual beans are decent as espresso, but really below average as drip.
author: Kevin T.

description: lovely place with great coffee! I love coming here to study, there are always enough tables and outlets to plug in your phone/laptop. Staff is friendly and outdoor seating area in the back is so nice and peaceful.
author: A J.

description:
Excellent ambiance for working. I don't drink coffee so I usually get the Kombucha. It's expensive ($7 per bottle!) but tasty and worth it for the work space.

Wifi is good. They have power strips.
author: Max H.

description: Ample natural light. Wooden tables of different sizes and even a couch. Most people here are working on there computers. I came here and found it a good place to get some work done. The $3.00 limeade was not great though. Otherwise, a great atmosphere to be productive. Next time I want to try the back patio.
author: Grains P.

description:
This place is super awesome, hip, cool. The coffee is great, seating is excellent, music is cool. There is also outdoor seating at the back. 
Highly recommended.
author: Sachin G.

description:
The space is very nice. Unfortunately the dude behind the counter seemed rather set on being just plain old mean and unwelcoming. My friend and I both smiled and I said hello. He made eye contact, so I know he heard us. But he declined any type of response, and actually frowned on the hello.

The general vibe he let out was very counter to why I think coffee shops exist- to provide a friendly, positive environment to be and enjoy coffee.  I had high hopes, but why would anyone want to go somewhere so uninviting, when there are so many friendly coffee places just a few feet away?
author: Jumal Q.

description:
This is a serious place for the laptop crowd - meaning, they've created an environment suitable for working, studying or writing.  The space is airy with high ceilings, the wood benches aren't too uncomfortable, the secure wi-fi is free, there are abundant power outlets, and the vibe is very mellow.  They serve De La Paz and Ritual Roasters coffee and sell various pastries including mini cupcakes from Mission Minis, cookies, muffins, and croissants.  If parking weren't such a pain on weekdays, I would be a regular.

* Morning bun: small, chewy with crunchy edges and a crunchy bottom, flavored with cinnamon and a hint of orange, a little drier than I like but good
* Latte ($3.50): had a good, smooth flavor but seemed somewhat watery and not made with true skill

Parking is likely to be an issue during the week (it's hard to find in this area).
author: Lolia S.

description:
The Good
-Great space
-Minimal feel
-wonderful woodwork

The Bad
-Drinks are not a priority
-Coffee is gross

...I wish I could bring my Philz into Haus=/
author: Max H.

description:
I was in the Mission and needed a place to work for a couple of hours. Haus was quiet, bright and spacious. It has free internet, many tables, and several outlets. Many people were also working. The patio in the back was great. 

I got a green tea that was okay. I like the tea strong. Theirs tasted watery. But what really put me down about Haus was the attitude of the baristas. Maybe I am being unfair to them, because I was there only once, but my first experience wasn't pleasant. I got annoyed with their hipster attitude. They made me feel that they were making a huge favor to serve me a cup of tea. 

All things considered, it's still a pretty good place to go work.
author: Isaac H.

description:
Alright, it's nice to have unlimited wifi and your own table away from any noise in a spacious cafe. People with laptops will like it here - they've got outlets, and plenty of small tables.

But this café has no character. I was excited to check out a place that seemed like it had "Scandinavian influences" - whether in interior design, or furniture. I was disappointed. The barista had no expression whatsoever, the walls were plain and bare, the entire space just felt boring and uninspiring. There's a difference between refined simplicity and.....a space with nothing but boring tables.

Outdoor patio at the back can be pretty cool in the summer I guess. The chairs weren't that comfortable though.

Music is a bit of everything, which can get distracting. 

Coffee was not bad, but I bet it would've tasted that much better if I were in a nicer space.
author: Jackie C.

description:
Because of the good reviews, I decided to give this place a shot. But turns out, it was too quiet for me. It's true: this place has the ambiance of a library. Definitely not a place to kick it with a friend or with a study buddy-unless you wanna bring your convos outside, where the sun cooks you and keeps your drinks warm. The barista was bland and not welcoming, the people are very hipster. 

Perfect place if you need "you time". Worse place to catch a belly laugh.
author: Michelle C.

description: I came here for a cappuccino around 9am and was in a out in a few minutes. And I would love to come back here to sit and drink coffee because there's a beautiful outdoor patio and lots of sitting space. The vibe was quiet but it looks like a nice place to relax. The cappuccino was very good as well.
author: Lauren G.

description: It's a beautiful space, with a lovely back yard. Plenty of tables and outlets to get work done. The barista was very friendly but gave both me and the person in front of me the wrong order.
author: Emily D.

description: Ample outlets, good wifi, awesome beverages. Lovely outdoor seating, too! I got their iced almond milk latte ($4.50 a bit pricey) and it was so good. Perfect place to go get work done! Not so great for chatting / catching up with people. But there's Philz across the street for that!
author: Michelle K.

description:
The coffee is very rich / nice. You can tell a lot of coffee beans go into it. Some could think it's a bit too bitter, though.

Music not as good as 780 Cafe.

The decor is WONDERFUL. Really simplistic, well lit, clean and the perfect atmosphere to get work done. People here generally have headphones in and are rather quiet, so it's a really great place to get work done if you're motivated by that kind of thing. You almost feel a bit guilty if you're facebooking or something. Not so great if you and anther person are having a meeting / catching up after a while because it's rather quiet in here and you I'd feel self-conscious being too loud....

The patio in the back is great, maybe if you're going to have a meeting, go there. Also the patio is warmer than most patios as it's in the warmer part of town.

Another thing I like about this place is that they have extension cords with tons of plug spots and really fast, reliable internet.

**Word of advice: don't sit on the booth side seats, they are a little high for the table and you'll find yourself slouching!

***Change # of stars from 4 to 3 on 10/1/2012 because I realized I ranked Haus the same as Arlequin when i distinctly prefer Arlequin...***
author: Neeharika B.

description: Solid coffee, beautiful space. Lots of indoor and outdoor seating, great daylight, lots of shiny wood. Practically no food though, just a handful of pastries. Also only one person working during the AM rush, which seemed a little unfair to her.
author: Levi P.

description: Wonderful ice lattés. As good as Blue Bottle arguably. But the bathroom is perpetually filthy. Read my lips, "never clean." I sometimes choose Philz across the street so I'll have suitable facilities to use.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Nice strong coffee. Particularly their iced coffee.

Clean, modernist feel inside. High ceilings plus outdoor seating make working and/or reading here very comfortable.

Personally I prefer the tables facing outside -- what could be better than people-watching while sipping a latte and stalking people on Facebook?
author: Elaine W.

description:
This is a pretty spacious and chill coffee shop. I saw a bunch of folks working on their laptops or doing homework. The vibe in here is nice and the blueberry muffin I got was quite tasty. Lots of basic things and the wifi code cracks me up. "YouAreHot."

The guy at the front of the counter kinda reminded me of Edward from Twilight. He was a bit more hipster and less pasty though.

They have an awesome looking back patio so if it's a nice day, I bet they'll have more people here. 

I felt kind of bad chatting on my phone here because sound doesn't travel well here.
author: Amy J.

description:
Haus, you witnessed me sitting alone for hours with your minimalist interior and serene outdoor patio. Working. Playing. Procrastinating. Learning. 

I have drank many pots of your yerba mate, instagrammed too many pictures of your coffee, eaten your pastries both savory and sweet.

Haus, like your name, you feel like home.
author: Jane K.

description:
I love coffee don't get me wrong. I need it to stay awake...for school...to study....to live, but I wouldnt call myself a coffee expert. With that in mind, I really enjoyed Haus's coffee, however, they gained a 5-star review from me for a plethora of other reasons. While I am no coffee expert I am paticular about which coffee establishments I visit since I spend hours there studying.
1.Price/Selection 4/5:I love my coffee but I am not going to spend $10 to get my daily fix. Haus offers fair prices for an array of coffee, however, their lack of snacks/food is why it only gets 4/5 since it is lacking. 
2.Music/Noise Lvl 5/5: I have visited this coffee shop multiple times and usually it is not jammed pack and ridiculously noisy by customers. You cannot control the people around you, however, you can control the background music, machinery used, employees, etc and they do a perfect 5/5 job. My only recommendation would be to turn down the music volume by one level. 
3.Stud-a-bility(env which one can study) 5/5: With many tables, power strips, and couches, this is by far one of my favourite study places in SF. I have a favorite table, which I wont disclose, but all the spots are within feet of a plug. This has solidified me as a repeat customer
4.Bathroom 4/5: Face it, SF has thee worst bathroom situation. Most of them are freakishly small, smell, dirty, and I can go on and on. Haus bathroom is kept clean, almost always smell free, decent in size, and while I wouldnt say its the place to pee (it is a public bathroom after all) it does an above average job. 
5.Decor/Env 5/5:While my nose in generally stuck in my books/laptop I do raise my head occasionally and look around. They clearly planned out how they would design their coffee shop and they did a bag up job. It is no Ritz-Carlton, but in comparison to other coffee shops in SF, Haus is in my top 10 in having a clean design and layout.
author: Soroosh A.

description: Best thing about this place is the back patio on a nice day.  Inside is a hipster paradise with everyone on their MACs.  Not sure why, but they have trouble keeping the same staff so the quality of the drinks is a crap shoot.  They use Ritual Beans, but that only gets you so far...
author: Neal M.

description:
Haus is within my neighborhood and is usually my second option when Philz is full. They brew the same coffee as the one you can get @ Ritual Coffee Roasters, but unlike ritual, it doesn't get very loud and noisy in here here and it usually has ample seating. 

However, there is a dark, evil side to Haus and that deducts two points from them. CUSTOMER SERVICE! The baristas here have a huge attitude fix, and I say that with no reservation. 

That's Haus for you, not my first preference coffee shop but definitely a decent place to get some good coffee and work done in peace.
author: Parijat K.

description: Love this place. Good coffee, no frills setting, got WiFi, nice music and not too noisy. I find this place effective for both meetings and work sessions.
author: Itamar R.

description:
Suppeeerrrrr hipster which is almost pretentious and boring.

The place has really wooden hard chairs that looks cool but doesn't feel cool.  The music is pretty loud and so is that damn espresso machine.  The place is COLD.  Bring gloves.

The service is almost as cold as the coffee shop...and the coffee at that. 
Coffee is very sour and....well, disgusting.  I had to switch to tea and throw out that expensive cup of cold sour crap.

But really, if I lived next door or something i'd head over every couple of months when I was bored but i'll never treck over there again.  Not the worst experience ever (which would warrant a 1), but an overall negative one.
author: Roxanne A.

description:
Spent a whole friday afternoon and evening here to studying -- 

the good seats are quite hard to get because it's quite flooded with others. The ambience is nice because customers are quiet. No small talks between. They have plenty of outlets. Cappuccino was around $3.81. Don't quote me pls! it was pretty small but enough for me. What irritated me the most was the music that they played..it's so loud and was really hard for me to concentrate even with my ear phones. They were very hip hop-ish accompanied by a nasty bass sound. I guess it suited the crowd? Not so sure. Parking is difficult if you're driving -- mostly meter. On the plus side, they have outdoor study areas towards the back which is great for outdoor studying if the weather permits! Oh and if you're overwhelmed from studying with a friend, there's a great nail shop near by to relax -- Center Nails!
author: Karen T.

description:
Best place to do some focused coding!  These guys ought to be getting kickbacks from local tech firms.

The environment here is quiet: as if socializing falls outside a (silent!) social norm.  The music is generally mellow, or at least not distracting.  The wifi runs strong here.

It's always full of Silicon Valley tech workers and students.  In fact, today the "wfh" Facebookers and Googlers lined the east wall of the cafe, all absorbed in open Macbooks, and the students lined the west wall of the cafe, similarly absorbed open Macbooks.  It was like a high school dance, with all the girls on one wall and all the boys on the other.  Charming!
author: Alex H.

description:
It's true -- the first thing you notice when walking into Haus Coffee is the blank gaze of patrons seemingly plugged into their laptops.  Whatever happened to the good ol' days of Mission cafe culture, when you could read the latest from Foucault or chat with exiles from Pinochet's Chile?  The passage of time, I suppose.  

Nonetheless, Haus is a pretty cool place.  The space is impressive.  Light & airy, it somehow packs 'em in without feeling claustrophobic.  And although others have complained about the music, I kinda like Black Sabbath and the latest electronica.  Again, while others have expressed disdain towards the insolent barristas, I've found them neither insufferable nor self-consciously ironic, e.g., a typical Mission hipster.  In fact, the guy who works afternoons and evenings is always pleasant and makes excellent espresso drinks, the beans provided by Ritual.  

Although I don't think I'll bring my laptop to Haus anytime soon -- even the libertarian Wired types would frown on my porn-surfing habits -- I've always felt welcome there with my small pile of archaic printed matter.
author: Paul D.

description:
I come here when I need to throw on some headphones and do some work on my computer.  I'm a pretty boring black coffee drinker, but they do have a nice selection of coffee from different roasters around San Francisco.

If you're looking for a place with wifi and a quiet environment to get work done, you'll find it at Haus.
author: Matt H.

description:
Haus in an intriguing combination of appealing and freaky.  
Kinda like you.

Haus can feel tranquil one day
and sterile the next. 

Inside there are many individuals in communion with screens.
If you want quiet, this is it.
 
Sometimes the tranquility morphs into stifling; the absence of human eye contact combined with the insentient employees (they're trying to evade pod people by hiding emotion-have mercy) can make me feel like jumping out of my skin.

On those days the patio looks like an oasis...life! earth! sun! green!...in contrast to the silent interior of wires, glinting rectangles and staring skulls.

They have a few edibles...and there's evidence that the Quality Fairy lights down here.
They don't have much to eat, but what they have looks good.

The music is not too loud, hopefully it stays that way, otherwise I won't be haunting Haus.
author: Lame Lake Meese Z.

description:
Haus coffee is a shop you stumble into. It's not sexy like Ritual Roasters or sanctified by the Coffee Gods like Philz, but what it lacks in pedigree it more than makes up for in practicality: fitting given its German name. Looking straight from an IKEA magazine, the 20 feet ceilings, white-washed walls, and simple décor clarifies it's purpose: Get work done. 

It succeeds in most respects. Grad Students, Aspiring Writers, and Mission Techies flock to the location. My only criticism? A over-abundance of Heavy Metal music. My recommendation? Bring a good set of headphones.
author: David M.

description:
A great place if you would like to get some work done. It's definitely minimalist but the modular seating allows you to move tables together easily of you want to work with a few people.

The staff is friendly enough, although some of my friends have complained of subpar service. The best thing about this place is the outdoor patio in back. On a nice sunny day it feels pretty spectacular to be working outside.

The music is hit or miss depending on who is manning the counter. I'm sorry but sometimes techno isn't conducive to working or having a conversation.

Also, points to the staff for not even blinking when my coworkers and I show up with extension cords and set up a mobile office in the patio complete with conference calls and meetings.
author: Casey S.

description: You're probably not cool enough to be here. The WIFI password is an SAT word, because they don't want you here if you're not smart. You can order a chai tea latte with soy milk, but if you do you'll get a sour look back. They don't actually know what they are doing and are super unfriendly. Also the barista said "Spätzle" incorrectly, but he works at a place called Haus...
author: Cait G.

description:
Oh Haus, I want to like you. No, I want to LOVE you. You're attractive, well-priced, and a good break from the sometimes dodgy area this side of the Mission.

The deal breaker? What in the name of all things good and decent is going on with this music! I'm sitting here--right now--in the comfy couch by the window in the back. I want to stab myself in the ears so I don't have to hear any more of this. My MP3 player is at max. The earbuds are as deep in my ears as physically possible without minor surgery.

The first few minutes you played great ambiance music at respectable volumes so I ordered, cuddled up with a friendly looking chair, and started working. What happened in the last hour that made you decide "I've GOT it! Coffee houses need more deafeningly loud amateur quasi-death metal fret wanking music!"

No, Haus. No, they don't.

At this point I don't remember if I liked your coffee. What did I get? It was decaf...I seem to remember some odd stipulation about what you can make decaf. Oh, also there was ice in it. That was back when we were still getting along, Haus, so please forgive me if I've blocked more recent memories.

I have a sneaking suspicion that the barista is playing DJ with that computer of his behind the counter. Please Haus--and I never thought I'd say this--please invest in a Muzak. If you really want to use your laptop, I hear Pandora has some decent music, but I'm not sure you can be trusted to pick it yourself.

Fix your music, and we'll talk.

Also, the misguided excuse for "music" that's been playing while I wrote this review has featured a cowbell ON EVERY SINGLE BEAT for the last 3 and 1/2 minutes. Straight. For the sake of Will Ferrell's memory, give it a break! 

And now there's a lady screaming? Screw it. I'm going to Philz.
author: Brett P.

description: This place rocks! Super quaint décor and their iced coffees are amazing.
author: Mariana F.

description: Very nice place to sit outside on the back porch and drink fine coffee while reading a book. Thanks for this SF spot!
author: Michael S.

description: Spent Sunday afternoon here one day, getting some work done and enjoying a latte. Great space, plenty of tables inside and a great outside deck in the back as well. This place has a mellow, quiet vibe, everyone here was quiet and respectful of space and noise. Service was nice and pleasant. Will definitely be back for another weekend afternoon.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Like many of the other reviewers said, if you can get over the painful music choices and pretentious snobby baristas this can be a nice place to sit at a wooden table and work. 

It was my first time here, and I just stood awkwardly to one side as I waited a good few minutes for one of the baristas to make eye contact and take my order. The way one of them talked kept making me feel like she was doing me a HUGE favor, charging me $4 for a Caffe Latte and giving me the wireless password. 

Said Caffe Latte was actually pretty tasty, light and a sizable amount. 

The back patio area has some shade but all the good spots for working are inside. Although you will have to endure some odd music choices and transitions, like a bunch of light wailing followed by an hour of really loud Weezer.
author: Connie C.

description:
I'd like to give 4 stars for the cafe Americano, the patio in the back, the light wood decor & comfortable seating, however the music was abominable. I tried to stay hoping it would get better, but like a bad film, it just spiraled towards demise. I escaped.
Coffee:: good
Staff: pleasant
Music: Guantanamo torture quality (I think some cafes purposely do it to drive the campers out)
Try Sugar instead.
author: Julie G.

description:
My review of this cafe is in no way directed at the people who work there or the service but rather the crowd of people who attend here.  Service is great, friendly and the pastries and cappuccinos very good.  Seating arrangement great and design of cafe very interesting.

However, the people who go to this cafe are rather distant and even more so than a typical Starbucks location.  I'm actually not comparing Haus Cafe to a Starbucks because that wouldn't be fair but the point is, at a Starbucks, you usually meet the same kinds of people but can still get a conversation going or at least talk to people.

With Haus Cafe, it seems everyone is in their own group and they're techaholics (as in the typical techies who are more interested in their tech work than mingling).  One customer was about to sit down next to me and I had my notebook computer bag next to his seat and the tone of his voice, when he asked me to move his bag, seemed to be an anti-social, robotic tone.  First off, I didn't know my bag was in his way but regardless, the customer didn't even say "thank you."

The odd part of the Haus Cafe is that it's located at Folsom St. near 24th & Mission so well within the Mission District but also around a lot of Mexican restaurants & communities and other mom 'n' pop shops, bakeries, etc.  This cafe though is out of place in the Mission and belongs more in Downtown SF or nearby in SOMA.  Maybe Haus Cafe is emblematic of why a number of long-time residents of the Mission are getting sick and tired of how the tech industry is invading their communities and affecting culture adversely.
author: M B.

description: If you're strolling down 24th street, Haus pops up just as you start to think to yourself you can't handle the smell of urine for one more step. They serve Ritual coffee (without the judgement) in a more comfortable setting than Ritual itself. The outdoor seating area in back is a really nice place to spend a sunny morning or afternoon. The staff is friendly and they know what they're doing.
author: Marcus C.

description:
UPDATE: HAUS NOW TAKES CARDS!

Before I begin, know that I don't base my rating on the actual taste of the coffee. It's all sorta the same to me. I, personally, look for amenities when I go to coffee shops. That's because I only go to coffee shops when I'm looking for a place to get work done.

So now that that's understood, I have to say I really really really like Haus. It's clean. Both in the sanitary sense and in the design sense. Upkeep wise, the place is never dusty or dirty, and the bathroom is almost always spotless. As for design, it's very minimalist. Bright, unadorned white walls, and impeccable, slick wood furniture make up the guts of the place. But the very high industrial wood ceiling and fantastic lighting scheme mixed with an all window storefront are what really give it the bright, crisp, and modern feel. Add chill music, super fast reliable wi-fi, nice-enough baristas and a backyard area, and you've got yourself a great coffee shop for all day work/chill sessions. Oh, and did I mention the coffee is strong as hell?

The only drawback? Closes at 9pm.

Prices: 2 bucks for a small, 2.50 for a large coffee.

That's fair as I'm concerned.

Overall, Haus is legit.
author: Gil M.

description:
After having lunch in the Mission, my buddy, a local resident, suggested we go grab a coffee and, since I like coffee, I agreed.  We entered Haus and I immediately thought we had stumbled into an Apple commercial or silent flash mob of Mac book using ultra hipsters and I was horrified.  "Oh God NOOOO!" I thought to myself and then I turned and saw the unbelievably lame ironic WiFi password posted on the register: "Surreptitious" and just knew I had entered the holy hipster hell of the mother scratching planet!  I was sure at that moment that I was being watched and if I made one wrong move, a gang of skinny, shabbily dressed, pre-pubescent beard wearing, Radio Head loving (only on Vynil and not the song Creep) freaks were going to tie me up with their iPhone headsets and launch me out into the street in front of a Muni bus!  However, since i was with a friend and we were in his neighborhood and he's never steered me wrong with his recommendations for places for me to take people in the city, I took a couple of deep breaths and decided to just go with the flow.

Once my cultural panic attack subsided, I realized something was missing from Haus...the loud and awful music blasting one hears at places like Starbucks.  I also noticed the lack of people marching up to the counter and barking out something along the lines of "Frappe mocca cappuchini delux with four pumps and almond soy frazzledoonie!" like a militarized robot.  It was actually quite refreshing and I was starting to dig this joint.  Don't get me wrong, I still had my head on a swivel, constantly on the watch for a surprise hipster attack but I was starting to feel very at ease, almost calm and comfortable.  I was becoming one with Haus Coffee.

We got to the counter and were greeted by the girl working there who, let's just be honest, was very pleasant to behold, who took our orders (double espresso for me and a macchiato for him).  Side note here, my friend, who may or may not be Irish, laughed and called me the C word right in front of the pretty girl when I asked him what the hell a macchiato is.  (No really, what is it?).  Then we sat at a table near the outdoor patio.

Here's where it gets good, we sat down, it was quiet, and out of nowhere, some guy walks up and asks us if we mind if he sits at the table next to us (had an outlet on the wall).  I was shocked.  Imagine in today's world, some person actually considering that another person may not want them to sit right next to them when there are other tables open and having the courtesy to ask if it's ok?  Did I stumble into some strange vortex where people are actually polite?

Our drinks came out and instead of being in some cardboard cup that smells like a shoebox with a sleeve, they were in these strange containers I remember from olden times called 'cups'.  I had to look at my cup for a minute and try to remember what the purpose of the hoop shaped thing sticking out of the side was....oh yes, it is to hold the cup like a civilized person so you can enjoy your beverage.  Sweet mother of crap I love this place!!!

I don't even remember what the espresso tasted like.  For all I know, the lady behind the counter could have emptied an ash tray into a cup of hot water, stirred it up and served it to me.  What stood out the most about Haus was that:
1.  It wasn't a pain in the ass
2.  It wasn't filled with annoying dipshits
3.  Music was not loud
4.  People were not loud
5.  Everyone, including the customers were polite
6.  My drink was served in an actual drinking vessel

Place is so awesome, I might just go out, buy some skinny jeans, not shave for two weeks, and go hang out there all day long and surf the web!  Well done Haus, well done!
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Good espresso - Ritual coffee.

Good work cafe - lots of plugs and wi-fi. They also have an outside area with fewer plugs but nice on a sunny day.
author: Sid R.

description:
This place gave me a stomach ache the other day. "Why," one might inquire, "would he give a place that caused him stomach distress a full five stars?" Well, because the pain was due to my inability to stop eating their freakishly delicious vegan baked goods. In other words, it's my own damn fault.

It was a Saturday morning and they had an assortment of hip-hop cranking to my delight which was great while waiting in a line that went out the door. The baristas and other staff were definitely not at a loss for ass shaking moves creating quite the Saturday morning ambiance. 

I relaxed with tea while being serenaded by the likes of Mike Jones over the speakers, and spent so much time I kept going back for more of the vegan goodness. First the vegan pumpkin bread, then the vegan apple bread and lastly the vegan zucchini bread. I could. not. stop.

So yea, great tea, great atmosphere, helpful staff, and freaking amazing vegan bakery. Just remember, if you eat too much it's your own damn fault too.
author: Justin N.

description: I come to Haus when I just want to slowly enjoy a cup of coffee in a nice quiet space. I feel like their backyard is a hidden gem.
author: Priscilla M.

description:
Expensive coffee, no refills, terrible music.

Aside from that, nice comfortable interior.
author: michael p.

description:
I don't let this happen very often, but occasionally, just sometimes I run out of coffee beans. I am an addict. I have a grinder and an espresso machine. And a cafetiere. And a little cup-top drip thinger. 

Yep.

Sooooo, when this occasionally happens, and I am at home, and it is the morning time, I have to run out and buy some. We all know that the demise of  Mission IGA left some sort of crackhead-at-3AM shaped hole in our community, but it also sold a small selection of coffee beans. And so, in a pinch, I have once before run out to Haus to purchase some Ritual espresso beans.

The first time this occurred, the lady happily sold me a half pound and sent me on my merry (albeit slightly headachey, but merry nevertheless) way. I used them and then went out and bought my regular coffee and all was well in the land.

Having travelled much this past month, I found one lovely rainy morn that my grinder was without beans. My word! I pulled on my rain slicker and trudged out into the weather to the closest cafe to me that does not have a queue down the block (...insert a ponderous sound here...) to purchase a half pound of Ritual espresso beans. I would have even bought a full pound if it would have made someones life more convenient. I mean, I'm easy like a Sunday morning, I just need a damn coffee in the morning, especially on a Sunday. (This wasn't on a Sunday, but it's true.)

Haus is literally one minute from my house. This becomes important in this story very soon.

So I am standing there, and the lady asks me for my order and I ask about buying some beans. 

Blank stare. Sigh. "Wouldn't you rather just go to Ritual?"

Blank stare again, but this time it was on my face. "Well, I'm....ummm....well...."

I could go on with this story, but it was mumbly, and ended in me leaving, not exactly angrily. The feeling I had was more of a gentle bemusement, with a slight caffeine headache on the side. The anger came a few moments later, outside, when I had to find another way to get coffee. Have you ever attempted that without having first had a coffee?

If picking up the phone to find out how much coffee by the pound costs is too much of a bother, perhaps working in cafe is not the way to go about things.

The End.

PS I have never liked this place, but I bear it no ill will. 

PPS Put some art on the walls. The stark thing is so 1999.
author: Ima D.

description:
I've been coming here about once a week for a few weeks, to be surrounded by working people in a pleasant environment. It's great for this purpose, and would also work well for reading a book.

It has almost everything i could want in a "working" cafe
--Good coffee
--A warm and comfy atmosphere
--Enough seats/tables to get one every time
--Consistent, free WiFi
--Enough plugs to go around
--Eclectic music at a medium volume so i don't feel the need to put in headphones with my own selection
--Friendly baristas

Also, there's a patio out back for when it's warm (which i haven't tried since it's definitely not warm enough and won't be for a while).

The things it doesn't have are hard to come by in general, but they are the reason i can't give it five stars: 

--Gluten-free eats are limited to expensive raw chocolate products
--Tables are too high for good ergonomics when using a laptop
(I don't believe i've ever been to a cafe that has good ergonomics for laptop use, but i've been to some that come closer)
author: Juli C.

description:
I like this place. Excellent for plugging in your laptop, putting on headphones and diving into your work.

It's bright inside, the Wi-Fi is fast and their limeade is killer.

The seats are hard wood, so you might want to bring a cushion if you plan on staying a while.
author: Shawn C.

description:
As someone who spent 4 years living in Seattle, let me tell you!! I know a good latte. I gotta say that Haus served up the best latte Ive had in this city yet - could definitely hold its own with the heavy hitters up in the Emerald City. 

Furniture is spartan, which gives it a nice look but is not the easiest on the tush. All around though, pretty dern good. Including the banana pecan muffins.
author: Zack R.

description: Wanted to go to philz but it was closed for renovations. The regret of the day was to go to Haus! The "music" playing was some kind of torture device. It was instrumental pseudo intellectual crap that gave me anxiety. The iced tea was the worst I've ever had. It was mostly water and had a mold smell. I drank it anyways. I was thirsty, what can I say.
author: Bobby M.

description: I love this place. If Haus were a city, it would be the capital of Laptopistan. Very hip and modern. The ambiance is warm and productive. The music is actually very intriguing if you listen to it. You'll hear some band singing about teasing Nazis or something equally quirky and unique. Very mission. I come here to get work done and for a great cup of coffee on a regular basis.
author: Kevin G.

description:
A-OK sums it up.

I love that they have House Kombucha here.

The inside is like a library for laptop users. If you're alone, and want some quiet while having a coffee and using your laptop this is the absolutely the place for you.

The patio is nice for groups and talking as long as the weather is okay. A good spot for having a cup and then leaving. I wouldn't want to hang out there for more than just a little bit.
author: Emily C.

description:
Step up the game, Haus!  I love the warm wood interior.  The rest of Haus needs an overhaul:
* The coffee here is pretty one note - probably B flat.
* I tried a chocolate chip cookie and it was stale.
* The outdoor patio has too much pavement. I sat out there for 25 minutes and most patrons kept moving chairs and tables and umbrellas trying and failing to find a comfortable spot.
author: Ivan L.

description:
Cool looking place, but I just didn't jive with the staff. They were super snobby, and clearly had many other, much better things to do then help paying customers. 
Coffee wasn't bad, but it wasn't anything to write home about either.
author: dance f.

description: Very nice European contemporary. Super cool back patio. Wifi. And something _is_ up with their coffee. My service was great.
author: Will D.

description: I love this coffee shop! There is a lot of space and it's a great place to read a book or study. Jon is the best barista!!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Great place to work in, power outlets, wifi, bright, natural light and outdoor seating oh and pretty might fine coffee. 

Definitely a day time winner
author: Jade H.

description:
Most of my dissertation has been written here. Like many other have stated, Haus is a great place to get work done. The music is usually good, and not too loud in case you're not into it. The baristas are nice and never snotty. So far everything I've ordered has been made well. I typically just get coffee, black, which usually looks/tastes like a medium roast. They use Ritual and De la Paz beans.

Plenty of power outlets, WiFi, outdoor seating, and clean bathroom. Sometimes busy, but usually quiet.

If they had sandwiches or something other than pastries (which are yummy), I would probably stay there all day. Come to think if it, that might be intentional..
author: Emmanuel Z.

description:
I recommend Haus for the venue
You can sit outside in the patio which is very pleasant. Good place to work also
However I did not find the barrista friendly. Also the expresso and the ice tea we ordered were not very good
author: Joanna B.

description:
I love it here. I went here to do an out of work meeting on laptops and it was perfect.  Everyone was on laptops, working, it seemed like.  

Nice and clean, minimal fuss, super nice outside area.  To the point, coffee, something to eat with your coffee to stabilize your blood sugar, wifi.
author: Best M.

description:
I love this place! Great spot to work - sunny but you can see your computer screen. I also like their pastries and drinks. It's my favorite cafe in the city.

One recent problem though is keeping me away- too many fruit flies. They seem to be attempting to solve this problem using a mint plant to drive away the flies, but I would suggest they cover their pastries too until the fruit flies go away. A swarm of flies around the pastries makes them much less appetizing. I usually like to order a pastry when I go to a cafe and so now I'm not going to Haus because of the fruit flies! Hope they solve this soon...
author: Barbara W.

description: The place is beautiful, specially the backyard. They should only remove the "laundry" of this place so it would be even nicer. The option are not too many (only coffees and some pastries) but good.
author: Alice S.

description:
Haus has been operating in name-less secret for a short period now, but I finally found out its actual name through a website after I went to it a week or so ago.  Inside, there's a fireplace with a black leather sofa to sit on during those chilly SF nights.  I also hear they are opening the patio in the back soon.

Noe Valley Bakery brings in fresh baked items every day, and the coffee is pretty solid.  I have been told that Ritual and De La Paz are supplying the coffee and espresso.  Also, WiFi is available.

For now, I give it a 3 since it's not completely done.  I'll update once I go back to see it in its fully-completed state.

H ang out in this Mission coffee shop.
A dding a patio sometime in the near future.
U rban decor with an all-wood look inside.
S uitable for a relaxing afternoon or a casual date.
author: Kenny L.

description: The coffee is legit. I never eat anything there, though. I'm gluten free and the limited offerings they have don't seem appealing to me. ( chocolate and some kind of bar ) It would be great of they had some kind of savory food I could eat. It's great for working. It's quiet and has wifi and plenty of tables.
author: Cat M.

description:
We made a quick stop here on a Friday night for after dinner tea...
+Patio in the back.
+Great selection of teas, I didn't try the coffee. There's a really shiny espresso machine. If the coffee tastes and good as the machine looks, I'd increase my rating. 
+Efficient service 

-Closes early on Friday nights just like every other coffee spot in this hood
-Sterile atmosphere. Very quiet, minimalistic, etc. I suppose this could be a good thing but it was SO quiet, everyone was zoning out on their Mac and not conversing. It was awkward to be the only ones talking...thankfully someone left a copy of the NYT on the table.
author: Sara P.

description:
Delicious soy latte.

Quick, efficient and polite staff.

Spare, bright and naturally lit work area (with outside seating!).

Free speedy wifi.

Plentiful power strips (amazing!).

Great to awful music (please no more death metal mixed in with ambient).

I'll be back, but will ask the barista to press fast forward if necessary.
author: Justin H.

description:
I moved about a year-and-a-half ago from Seattle which is where my coffeeshop standards were mostly set.  I like a coffeeshop that has good coffee, nice work atmosphere (instead of baristas who give you the evil eye if you're there for longer than 30 minutes), free wifi, plenty of outlets, etc.  Haus has all of that so has become one of my go-to destinations.

A few things that I wish: A location with a little better people watching for getting distracted, later hours..and the regular weeknight barista is  friendly.

Bonus points for *not* trying to push out customers to close early.  Very appreciated.
author: Chad P.

description: Very nice place to work. Good music. However, not $ according to me, but more $$.
author: R G.

description:
Every time I come here I think, I really need to write a review about this place. It's almost amazing, but it's falling short in two main areas. They need to be said.

Pros: 
- Beautiful minimalist vibe. Great place to actually get work done.
- Usually good music.
- Lovely back patio.
- Cool crowd that works here.
- Coffee and coffee drinks are great. 
- Kombucha offered -- yes!
- Yerba Matte offered -- yes!!

Cons:
- GRUMPY BARISTA. Ugh. Ok. Seriously, what is the deal with the woman barista? She is always so damn unfriendly, and pretty uncomfortable to deal with. I honestly sometimes don't want to come in here because I feel a knot in my stomach having to talk to her when she is working, so I just go to Philz. 

I was at first offended by her extreme attitude toward me and how rude she was when I was simply ordering a coffee, smiling at her, being a normal customer, but chalked it up to her having a bad day. The next time I came in she was also rude and I thought, OK, this chick just really doesn't like me for some reason. Must be the way I look because she doesn't utter a word to me or ever return a smile or conversation, won't make eye contact with me on purpose (which is pretty damn rude when you are a cashier), yet obviously doesn't know me at all. (I mean, I don't look unusual or offensive, so nothing really makes sense here). The next time I came in I decided to try to engage her in conversation and kill her with kindness, trying to win her over. Uhh, no. That did not work. Super grump, no eye contact, purposefully being rude like she wanted me to know she didn't like me or that she was above me or something. Now it's just annoying. I"m not sure if she's one of the owners or just a barista, but I urge Haus to talk to her about her behavior to customers. Nobody wants to be in an uncomfortably unfriendly environment while they are trying to be simple paying customers. It quite frankly, sucks.

- Haus would REALLY benefit from adding some additional food options other than just pastries. I know some people like sweet pastries, and that's great... But when you are sitting there working for a long time, ordering more coffee or tea throughout the morning or day, sometimes you get hungry for something savory. Philz offers a ton of items, from savory philo dough bites to small breakfast burritos, to bagels with hummus.  I'm not sure what Haus has the capacity to heat up or make, but even anything savory at all would be nice, as not all of us can eat those sweets. I have on many occasions, left Haus and went over to Philz to continue working there, only because I got hungry and they had food. I can see Haus offering something like empanadas from the local Venga Empanada Bakery...  (That's what Sugarlump offers and it's great!)
author: Honey T.

description:
This place is super conveniently a few blocks from my apartment, and as a person who really does enjoy a well-made and non-burnt cappuccino, I'm glad to stop in every couple of weeks.

It's true that this place comes off as pretty pretentious - stark/austere interior, cold wave music, and baristas who are mostly too bored and over life to take your order quickly or with a smile. 

BUT - the coffee is actually really good, and for me that's what is most important. It's not as good as Four Barrel of course, but there are no other serious contenders this side of the mission. 

All that said, I usually get my cappuccino to go...
author: Rachel G.

description:
"So, do you wanna go to Philz or try Haus? It's new. They have Ritual Coffee." 
"Let's try Haus so next time, I'll know which I prefer."

Yeah, Philz for sure. Haus has a nice clean atmosphere, but it was like a funeral in there but with house music. Nobody was socializing and everyone was staring at a computer screen. It was weird and kinda erie. Plus, the people behind the counter were not friendly. It's that too cool thing I seem to encouter in coffee shops often. Anyone else feel me on that? Before I even took a sip of the coffee, the vibe turned me off. I'd try it again because the coffee was good, but I credit Ritual with that.
author: GHADA Y.

description: Nice coffee oasis for when you don't want the line at Philz. Great latte and they have yummy Sandbox baked goods!
author: Michael L.

description:
This place is a much cleaner, warmer, and pleasant place than Philz if you have to make a choice which to frequent.  I had a decent latte but was disappointed at the lack of pastries to chose from, even though it was fairly early enough to have a selection. I also wish they had more sweeteners to chose from. I prefer to pick my poison, and not be stuck with Splenda giving me a splitting headache later. 

The Wifi is good and the music was more ambient and chill when I was here so it was more relaxing than annoying so it was fine. The volume was also good. One drawback is the hard- assed wood seats which are killer on the ole L4/ L5 when its acting up. I prefer not to travel with my grandma doughnut so a few soft seats would be nice! This place has no real personality to speak of but I think that's why i kinda like it, and anything is better than filthy Philz.
author: Lisa J.

description:
AVOID!!! If you want to have a conversation, or be in an Internet cafe without having your ears assaulted, it's a no-go.

The coffee is fantastic (Ritual Espresso and De La Paz french press today), they have loads of plugs, the pastries look tasty, and the wifi was strong.

Unfortunately, the music was so awful our brains were scrambled and so loud that my friend and I couldn't have a decent conversation while we were working on our laptops. I see why every other person in the room was wearing headphones and was alone. 

I asked for the music to be changed once because it was some sort of piercing wailing and then loud jungle drumming. My friend went up and asked if the music could be turned down because it was so ear-numbingly loud, and though it got turned down a hair, it wasn't nearly enough. When we left, my friend again told the counter person we'd been driven out by the ear-scorching music, he shrugged and said "ok" as if our business didn't matter...

I suppose it's possible, as other reviewers have mentioned, that they pump up the music to get the table campers to leave, but that just seems ass-backward. I'm a fairly heavy tipper, buy lots of drinks and goodies when I'm at a cafe, and appreciate having power available for my laptop for a couple hours.

I'm bummed, because it's half a block from my house, and there's a pretty little patio out back that would be perfect for a refreshing afternoon of work away from home. 

But I won't be back.
author: SisterMable S.

description: I've been here twice in my short stint in SF, and it's one of my favorite spots. I absolutely love the space -- indoor and out. It's bright with plenty of tables, free wifi, good music, and good coffee. The staff are friendly, and folks are pretty chill. It's definitely a bright spot in the neighborhood.
author: Rae B.

description: I love this place because it's quiet, well lit, and always seems to have tables and outlets available. The coffee and pastries are average (they brew Ritual coffee), although I do enjoy the dark chocolate and sea salt cookie :) The patio in the back is also a great spot to catch up with friends or watch the people inside glued to their MacBookPros.
author: Jojo H.

description:
Went there at around 7pm at night.

It was my first time to be there, I liked the ambiance! It's a better place to get work done compare to Philz across the street. 

I had a brew coffee. It tastes pretty good.

Only complaint: The barista wasn't friendly. I am not going to judge why was that. Perhaps it was just my impression, perhaps it just happened she wasn't in a good mood. I am sure other customers had a good time there. 

I think I will go back again and I shall give another review again soon.
author: Mel C.

description:
Come here for the internet and to kill time.  The internet is free, and the drinks are average.  

I'm from LA and waited here to meet up with my sis.  The interior is modern, simplistic.  Barren might be a better word.  My sister seemed to recommend this over some others in the area cause they have an outdoor patio.  It was a sunny, warm day in SF.  
Being from LA, my computer hardly sees any coffee shops or wi-fi other than my home and the occasional Starbucks.  My tech jargon is weak, but my sister, who works at UCSF, threw all kinds of words around like 'cloud accessible' . '2 different server', yada yada yada.  To sum it up: the internet here works. And I updated my mac and watched Hulu with no problem.

The coffee was average coffeeshop coffee in SF. Nothing to walk an extra block for.  I also had a Yerba mate, which i have the same comment for.  There was nothing to munch on there at 3 pm. It made me wonder how they could stay open with people buying one coffee or espresso drink, and staying 1-2 hours for the free internet.

Super quiet place.  Everyone was on their silver Mac computer.  So if you are looking for a place for a coffee to catch up with a friend, or if you use a pc, this may not be the place.  But great for some surfing.
author: Xenoneon N.

description: This place is pretty awesome. Good coffee, good pastries, cool furniture, solid tunes, and a pretty bad@ss outdoor patio in the back. + 1 star for being the first four letters of my last name...completely subjective review.
author: Michael H.

description:
2 stars because you can get some work done here, but minus 3 stars for the environment and vibe. The coffeeshop looks interesting and modern from the pictures, and indeed it is, but the overall lack of warmth in the cafe is noticeable. I suppose I'd come back if I just needed a no-nonsense place to get work done, but the house/techno music playing in the background is a little too much to bear. I mean, if you're going to call yourself "Haus" and play house music, could you at least play something a little better and conducive to work than something that sounds like a German death chant?

The barista wasn't too friendly either. Not sure I'll be back.
author: Michelle G.

description: Very poor service. Unfriendly barista did not greet. I had the audacity to be looking at my iPad while waiting. Barista must have glanced up and without a word asked the next person in line for their order. After a minute or two she said, "Sorry, I thought you were busy." She had a slight smirk as she said this. I initially ordered my drinks, thought better of it and cancelled. I told her I would remember this. You hear about stuff like this, as the saying goes, but you never think it...   I can see now why some places can get a reputation.  Avoid this one
author: Mark M.

description: Snoody barista girl who was in a mood.  bothered by my good mood simple questions about the place.  The space is GREAT.  plenty of seating and awesome outside area.  My latte was ok, a little sloppy.
author: Jorge D.

description: It is what it is! A good place to sit and get some work done. Decent cappuccino, and slice of pumpkin bread was good and moist. Free wi-fi, and fun for people watching.
author: K R.

description:
I usually can't find anything wrong with coffee shops. Anything. If I do, I am quick to overlook it simply because I can brew coffee at home, or order one to go, or poach their free Internet, or talk to the interesting people there.
But Haus, this is simply a different matter. I am currently being repulsed by their coffee. It tastes like pea soup, and I drink my coffee black. The idea of bitter coffee isn't wild to me.
They also had IKEA tables and chairs. I know because I have the same cheap tables and chairs. Can you get away with that crap in the Mission? Apparently you can now.
The wait staff was ok, but they gave me the typical coffee shop sneer. "What would you like to order, you guy who is no where near as cool as I am?"
Skip this place. It was a mistake to be lazy and not go to Philz across the street.
author: Jeremiah M.

description: Meh describes my experience here. It was super short lived because there was no where to sit inside. Every seat was occupied by someone using their macbook pro for something apparently really important. The design inside is very minimalist as well, so the sterile ambience fit well with the decor. Lastly, the drip coffee was not very good. Heard good things about this spot, but once I went inside I was not impressed the slightest bit.
author: Maximilian R.

description:
As my good friends know, I love a place with exposed wooden beams.  Haus is such a place.  

This place is simple.  Coffee and espresso, cookies (and other baked goods), and wi-fi.  A nice, quaint place to work on a rainy day.  

Prices aren't bad.  $2.00 for an americano.  Showed up on a rainy Saturday, and seats (and power outlets) were abound.  

How's Haus? Fine, I say.
author: Marc P.

description: If you're easily distracted and prone to procrastination, Haus will help you meet your deadlines. The austere decor, bright lighting, and quiet environment discourage distraction. If you need an extra incentive, the hoards of productive laptop zombies will judge you and eat your brain as you check your facebook. With power outlets a plenty and a nice outdoor seating area, you could easily spend your entire day working at Haus. If you do, try a big mug of Orchid Oolong tea in between your perfect cups of espresso. It is divine.
author: Becca O.

description:
The first "review highlight" on Yelp is ""Great place to get work done."  (in 4 reviews)" This is a dirty, dirty lie.

When I take the day to work from home, away from distractions/phone calls/etc, I grab my laptop and head to Philz.  The din and ambient noise there is at just the right level for proper writing focus.  Unfortunately today they added loud construction noise to the bob marley & world cup & conversation noise, so I gathered up my stuff and headed across the street to Haus, where I will occasionally go for an americano if I know I have 10 minutes to spare for the elaborate espresso making process they engage in here (note: if there is a single person in front of you in line, you're looking at 10 minutes more, and they have only french press coffee which is always 5 minutes away from being ready to drink.  Starbucks this is not, which is awesome  for quality, bad for speed).

In any case, this is not a good place to work.  The music is TERRIBLE.  Really, really terrible.  As over caffeinated as I am right now due to having to switch coffee shops, the yelling & noise over a pounding beat "music" is making me want to stab someone, not finish my narrative.  And let's face it, the last time I tried to work here I had the same music-related troubles.

Peace out, Haus!  I'll see you in a few weeks for my americano, but peaceful work environment you are not.
author: Danielle H.

description: Quiet (relatively; they got the new-agey techno rock a little high).  Seems like a good to work.  Fast fast internet!  Thank you.
author: Griffin D.

description:
The mornings have great coffee and nice people.

But the afternoons seem to be plagued with those stuck up coffee snobs. You know those barristas that insist on making you feel unworthy of their art. Ya know what...take my money and let me enjoy my cup without the attitude thank you very much. 

On a side note the coffee is good but pray for a friendly barrista.

The ambiance is good but make sure you have a Mac or else you will stick out.
author: Joseph M.

description:
simple, clean design - wood, concrete combo 

The lattes are great, including the yerba mate tea and the african nectar tea. It does get busy by mid-day, often taken up by those with laptops and readings to do. I've spent a number of hours getting research done. If you want a relaxed coffee shop to zone out and do work - this is the place.

oh, and might i add - they have outlets for laptops!
author: T J.

description: There were more laptops here than people and everyone was camping. Just came to meet a friend for a quick cup of coffee and chat but there was no where to sit since everyone was busy in study groups. Nice if you get in first and can secure your table for the next three hours.. but kind of a bummer for everyone else. My Americana was good, but there were only about 10 menu choices.
author: A P.

description:
Disappointing.

I had high hopes when this cafe first opened.  Looks like they managed a nice minimalist look on a small budget.  Good for them.

Tried an espresso soon after opening and again more recently.  It was not well prepared (well, it didn't live up to the current high level, SF coffee culture standards).

Cafe was a bit dirty.  Back patio was more dirty.  During one visit, employee was cleaning the outside glass of the pastry case with a glass cleaner.  I'm for cleanliness, but don't know that it's a good idea around the customers.

Perhaps I'll try again in another few months, but I don't feel an urgency since there is a good alternative not far away.

At least, it seems that they are trying, which places it above some of the other nearby cafes, so it might do in a pinch.  I can't comment on the drip coffee.
author: Jice E.

description:
Ritual coffee, ACF cups, large patio, very warm inside, tall ceilings, concrete & wood design, a lot of free seating, free wi-fi + tons of power outlets, great bright lighting.

Great place to work and web surf. A bit less great to talk, as music is pretty loud.
author: Yury L.

description:
2.5 stars...
Clean, minimalist, free wifi.  It probably is a great place to get work done but the one time I needed to use it for this purpose all the outlets were being sucked dry by Mac using nerd hipsters.  
It's just a bit too pretentious.  The name, the decor, the music, the Ritual coffee.  I mean, really?  The vibe of this place already feels like a Ritual rip-off (and I am not really a Ritual fan in the first place), but to then serve Ritual coffee is just drawing attention to the embarrassment.
They have an outdoor area which has zero ambience but good for people who like their nicotine and caffeine in tandem.
The coffee is fine, I like that they have the mission minis cupcakes, and it really does seem like a good place to work.  I'll probably go back at some point.
author: Jane F.

description: As someone who "works from home" this is my FAVORITE place to work. I am most productive here. Probably because it's quiet here and full of others working from their laptops. Not the best place to have a conversation, maybe outside in the back patio area (because it's so quiet inside). The baristas are all delightful, especially April & Roland. Great coffee, environment, etc.
author: Dani S.

description:
Like a lot of people, I tried to go to Philz but it was packed.  Stopped in here because it seemed like a good place to work.  The coffee is rather good and nothing fancy, which is fine by me.  Wifi is free and a pretty solid connection, no complaints there.  The place is clean and modern looking with concrete floors and wood chairs, benches, and tables, which I like.  Big windows in the front and back, with a nice back patio that I imagine is great when the weather is nice.

The seating, unfortunately, is not the most comfortable.  The benches are too high for the tables and force you to sit awkwardly (I'm pretty average height).  You can sit in lower chairs, but then your back is to the door, which is not always great.  Also, the music is a bit distracting with heavy bass.  

Overall, not a terrible place but I don't think I can/want to stay here for very long.
author: Natalie H.

description: Extra points for outside seeing in the back, sleek decor and pretty much perfect espresso.  Didn't have them but the cookies from L'Acajou look delicious. Customers were kind of young and hip and a lot seemed to be seriously working but I did see *one* guy with a non-Apple laptop so I don't think you should feel like you have to have the perfect look to feel comfortable here.
author: Chris M.

description: I like this place, but the music is really angsty at times and ventures into the noise music territory. I want to come here much more, but I might have to wait until I get noise canceling headphones. There are plenty of great collections of music that works great at coffee shops, like e.g trip hop, so to the owners: this can be easily changed and if you do so I will send much love in the form of hard cash spent your way.
author: Andreas S.

description:
The BEST lemonade I have ever had. Not only is it homemade but I suspect there are ginger and nutmeg spices in it, which blew my mind away. Amazing! 

The outdoor seating area is nice, and overall this is a great place to just sit down and chill for as long as you want.
author: Lara N.

description: I only ventured in here because it was a beautiful morning, I was on a walk, and needed more coffee, a sparkling water, and the backyard looked inviting.  So that's exactly what I did.  I noticed the barista/cashier was in a mood and I was curious how she could be so down -- put on a happy face, you're making hearts onto lattes!  Anywho, not really anything special about this place but I liked the yard and probably a cool place to work or hangout if you need a coffee space for that.
author: e w.

description:
There is life where there once was none. 

I moved to the 'hood not too long after Haus first opened, and it wasn't a particularly special establishment. Excellent coffee and free wifi, but not much else in terms of atmosphere. I wondered how well it would fare with Philz just down the block, especially when Haus didn't seem to offer much in comparison.

However, I admire the business model behind Haus - open with not much besides the basics (Ritual and De La Paz coffee + free wifi), see if you attract customers (and keep them over time), then add the bells and whistles accordingly.

Since bare bones inception, Haus has moved gradually into the ranks of a real coffee house, with the addition of warmer lighting, fireplace and comfier seating, occasional live music (I swear I saw a live jazz trio in there once, lest my eyes deceive me), and an overall more down-home feeling. Yet another great coffee establishment on 24th St.

P.S. I apologize, again, to the folks at Haus for accidentally knocking over their big lovely glass tip jar one morning and causing it to smash all over the place. That was one of those moments when I wished the Earth would simply open up and swallow me whole. Curse my clumsiness.
author: Anna G.

description:
DRINK:
1.) Macchiato = espresso shot with a little bit of milk in it, looks like a mini little latte.


SERVICE:
free wifi, accepts credit card


ATMOSPHERE:
Ahh... an oasis in the middle of the ghetto-ass side of Mission. Open bright with lots of natural light, feels like I'm in a modern minimalistic home, with roughly refined industrial interior revealing the cement floor and unvarnished wood beams, tables, chairs; big bright back wall all window, to the cute backyard with more tables to enjoy the outside. Lots of outlets, which they considerately provided with the multi-outlet extension cords, and the other thing I need to work in a cafe - bathroom. YES. I'd come back here, but I just don't really like the neighborhood so much.
author: Angela L.

description: Today I stopped in requesting a latte with an extra shot in a 16 oz cup instead of a 12 oz cup.  Server was unwilling to do an extra shot (why?), as well as unwilling to serve me a latte in anything but a 12 oz cup (again, why?).  Poor form.
author: Benjamin K.

description:
They make good espresso drinks, have a really nice space,
and have so far been generally nice. What's not to like?
author: Max R.

description:
Marvelous place to get work done on a laptop or mobile device!

Free WPA-secured wifi
Plenty of outlets
Ritual coffee
Mighty Leaf tea
Outdoor patio area

If you're here to get some work done, it's perfect.  If you're here to meet a friend over coffee (as I see a couple patrons doing right now), Haus seems quite fine for that as well.
author: Pat D.

description:
Rollercoasteeeeer!
My final verdict is that espresso quality here depends on the barista's hand, his mood and the one of the guy roasting coffee at Ritual.
Yes, consistency is not their forte but it's still the best espresso cup on 24th together with Sugarlump, whose reliability is an option too.
Let's put it this way, depends on how much you want to walk and in which direction you're coming.
I also had a pleasant lesson yesterday on how to press the coffee into the barrel, without creating an uneven/slanted surface, that will affect the quality of the crema and the intensity of coffee. Nice!
author: Dario B.

description:
Does the music REALLY have to be so f***ing LOUD? Haus has good coffee and pastries, but no other food. It's spacious and has lots of outlets. So obviously they are encouraging people to come and spend some time working, yes? So why drive us out with music that is too loud?  Yes, some people abuse the privilege, but most of us are grateful for a bright, spacious place to work, and we will buy multiple drinks/pastries and leave big tips in the jar if we hang around for hours. Please, please, please turn down the music. Don't make me feel like an a-hole for having to ask. 

The two staff people I've experienced have been pleasant, unpretentious as previously noted, etc. Owner (at least I think he's the owner), not so much. Sigh. My search for the perfect place to work continues.
author: Chris P.

description:
Haus. one word. LIMEADE. Maybe two. FREE WIFI. ok three. OUT DOOR PATIO!

I'm definitely a fan of this out of the blue cafe down on 24 n folsom. The ambiance of this place is cozy, cabiny contemporary :) I'm hooked on their LIMEADE! classic sparkling soda water with a hint of lime juice & sugar. My cup of treat. I love the free wifi and it always caters to all the MAC daddies.  The vegan sea salt cookie is yummy too. On a hot day, a perfect chill out is outside backdoor patio with wifi. heeyy, it gets pretty good here ;} and its open to 9pm!
author: Fat C.

description:
While Starbucks is trying hard to recreate your livingroom in their cafe, Haus is a cafe with productivity in mind.

Some people might find the decor to be harsh and anemic, but I LOVE the modern, minimalist nature of this cafe, with lighting and wood everywhere, a simple menu, plenty of seating and outlets, and free unlimited wireless internet.

As it is somewhat of a trek to Haus from where I live, I have total cafe envy right now.
author: Jenn C.

description:
1. I almost missed this place because it's somewhat hidden in the middle of the block.
