2. The interior design is very bare and made me feel like I was studying in my basement.

3. The outside patio is nice when you need to study with some fresh air but literally feels like a backyard where they also keep their trash. It would be nice if they jazzed it up a bit.

4. Do not try the fizzy drinks.
author: Lily Z.

description: Best Americano I've ever had. The outdoor seating area is beautiful. Very serene. I was able to get a lot of work done here! It's not noisy like Ritual or any of the more populated cafes in the Mission.
author: Sharee R.

description:
Basic coffee, fine. Good pastry selection. And a Patio. But the overpriced pretension is a killer. 

I asked for a shot of espresso in a drink I was having and the barista smirked, made it, then charged me full price for a dbl shot espresso plus my drink. Without even offering me the second shot to drink since I paid for it. How was I to guess that they at Haus were on the espresso vanguard of not offering drink alterations: a tiny addition to the menu that says all shots double. And perhaps a cheap plywood reference to the other purist pretense that is Four Barrel.  Guess I'm just a plebeian with 7 years barista experience that won't bother going back unless Philz and La Victoria are closed.
author: l y.

description:
I love that this Cafe has nice lighting.  I hate when the ambiance is too dim and you can't get anything done.  There's also a nice warm fireplace in the back if you want to get warm ;)

Haus is a great place to get work done.  There are lots of outlets, great coffee, and depending on the time of day you arrive ... lots of seats.  The decor is a little minimalistic, but it's very fitting with the space.  The music ... they were playing songs from the inception soundtrack, THUMBS UP!  Oh and the bathrooms are clean (for the mission that is).  

I will be back!
author: Char C. B.

description:
From the outside this place had potential. Although there are now like a billion of coffee places on the block we decided to go here. You hear that Haus Coffee? We chose you over the other billions of coffee shops on the block - in customer service terms that means you must be nice and need to stand out from the other places. 

In addition - I lived in New York (both Manhattan and Brooklyn) so believe me when I say I know what hipsters are. We get it - you work at a coffee shop, don't shower, and really don't treat people nice. I get it. I get the message. I get the look. YOU"RE A F****** hipster. We all get it! However, your ass is serving me a coffee so lets be nice before this place goes out of business and you'll be back to being unemployed. 

I really don't want to rip a new business an a-hole bc I really do support the independent business shops and would like nothing more than 75% of starbucks removed but the service here was horrible. The barista took 10 minutes to make our coffees - we were the only ones that ordered anything. When asked about using an electrical socket we were told we couldnt' and to find one somewhere underneath a bench. I'm only giving this place horrible reviews b.c. of the service. That ruined our entire stay at Haus. 

The atmosphere inside is light and mellow. It isn't as overcrowded as Philz down the street but honestly the coffee wasn't good and service sucked. I'm boycotting.
author: Sasha B.

description: Simple and delicious.  Not a frilly spot but their back patio is perfect for soaking up sun in the sunniest microclimate in SF. And the solid wifi makes it a good spot to work.
author: Sasha W.

description:
Really really good coffee.  Lots of plugs.  Good music.  Charming outdoor space.

They don't offer much more than coffee, which is too bad because it means I can not stay all day... and I would, if I could.

(Also really nice guy works there. No pretension.)
author: Sandy S.

description:
Very good coffee (though not blue-bottle level), and the barista knew how to steam milk for an excellent cappuccino.  Also very nice location, cool patio, wifi, etc.  

I'd have given them five stars except for the wobbly table.  Is a wobbly table really worth a whole star, you ask?  And I say yes, because wobbly tables are a tragedy at a coffeehouse, because they invariably mean spilled coffee.  I probably lost a solid quarter of my cappuccino in a moment of knee weakness.  Not cool.
author: Paul G.

description:
Before I left Ritual, I wanted to find another spot so that I wouldn't just wander aimlessly and find myself at some crap coffee shop. I was led to find Haus, which boasted plenty of outlets (what I needed) and a nice, chill work vibe/space.

I can't comment on the coffee as I opted for green tea this time around. But the guy behind the counter did offer me a choice as they carry a variety of green teas. I just said that any would do, and he chose something similar to genmaicha, except less brown rice-y. It was good, and nice that I received a little pot that lasted me the whole visit.

With Haus slightly more tucked away from the rest of the Valencia coffee shops, it was a great option for work purposes. I kept my seat warm for a good 3-4 hours, and the amount of traffic was relatively light. By the time 5 pm hit, though, the shop started to fill up and seats went unavailable. And so, my proverbial work whistle blew and off I went to my next destination.
author: Karen T.

description:
Lovely open, modern space. Great place to work and lots of light. I'm not a coffee drinker, so I have nothing to say about the coffee. But their elixirs are great. We had the Rose Black Kombucha and the Blood Orange and Honey elixirs and they were both excellent.

The Blood Orange was refreshing, citrusy, sweet with a hint of lime. It's perfect for a hot summer day.

The Rose Black was interesting. If you know how Kombucha tastes, think of that flavor mixed with rose. It was strangely addictive.

All in all, a great little coffee shop in the mission with some very interesting drinks
author: Cindy C.

description:
i remember coming here when it  first opened the  service was  great and great  place to get work  done .
now the place is packed with  hipster with thier mac laptops and  not  enough power outlets b/c  everyone is  too busy  charging thier electronic products 
but the  food is  great always fresh  but  i do  recommend that  you get there early  if u want a good place to sit
author: W R.

description:
i LOVE their coffee and location but hate some of their pretentious barristas.  I keep coming back here despite their rude staff because, even though they brew ritual coffee, somehow it tastes better than at ritual itself :)

I was here once where this drunk guy came into the place and the cashier did absolutely nothing while the drunk guy bothered the women in the place.  I finally did something myself, kicked the guy out, and got thanked by all the women at Haus but nothing from the only person who should have thanked me: the cashier.

I would have given them five stars if it weren't for the staff :(
author: Banana S.

description:
I walked into Haus last night around 7pm for an iced coffee and felt like I had interrupted a private party. The crowd was so silent it was downright eerie.

Haus itself is minimalist. Lots of light and space, and clearly designed for those who want to come and work and not be bothered for seven or eight hours.

Still, the iced coffee was good.
author: Nick S.

description: Good coffee! Nice place to work because everyone around you is working too. Its a study bar!
author: Manu M.

description:
I first came here with a friend who wanted me to try something new. I couldnt get the iced coffee I wanted cause it was being french pressed (I couldnt believe it) and wasnt ready, so I was offered an iced Americano. Being a former barista, I was a little sketched, but tried it anyway, and found it was the best friggen Americano Ive had...ever. Even better then regular coffee (which till now topped the cake for me, Im plain like that).

Since then I came back a few times and only order the same thing. I usually feel safe with something just once, and never try anything different till what I like is out of stock, screwed up, or just not offered anymore - but Iced Americano is standard wouldnt you say?

The only thing I didnt like about this place, is that I felt the seating was a little mismatched for the amount of people. Lots of 4 seat tables occupied only by 2 people on MacBooks, and the little tables barely could seat 2 comfortably. But even with that, straight up 5 STARS because after all THIS IS A COFFEE HOUSE, and not some MacBook BAR! Right?
author: William D.

description: To put it bluntly, wow what a bitch. After waiting a couple of minutes while the barista was doing dishes with her back turned, I stepped over and attempted to order a drink, assuming she hadn't known someone had been waiting at the counter. I was met with thick attitude and annoyance that I wouldn't just stand there until she finished them all and got around to taking my order. Her face looked like someone who needed a diaper change. Really? I then tried to get change for a $5 bill SO I COULD TIP HER more than the 75 cents change I was given. More annoyance. Well how about I change it out of the tip jar, would you mind? Oh yeah, she sure would mind. Like I'm going to steal your piss ass $7 in tips while getting my change to tip you. I actually told her to forget it and left without any coffee.  Horribly rude attitude.
author: Heather W.

description:
One of the best coffee places in SF

The name does not lie. They have gone to great lengths to make this feel like a home. The decore is very welcoming and relaxing. There are nice tables and sofas. Also the sofa in the back has a lamp next to it which is awesome for book reading. 

Both times I have gone there has been a pleasant and very capable Barista working. They also have some delicious pastry.

I am planning to go on a sunny day since it seems to have a very nice and spacious back patio. Unfortunately it has always been raining when I have gone.

Finally, the music sometimes tends to make conversation difficult. They have a weird sound system which (i assume) is being fed by somebodies iPhone/Pod. Though I have mostly shining things to say about this place I have left once because the song playing was loud, distorted, and hard to talk over. It might have just been that day to be fair.

I like this place a lot!!!
author: Eric G.

description:
This is my ideal coffee shop!

The coffee: French press coffee with Ritual Roaster beans. Very good.

The internet: Free, fast and no hassle wi-fi. No coffee shop that I have been to has better internet.

This place is great for coffee and getting stuff done on a laptop. The place is clean, solid tables, cement floor. They also have a nice back patio.
author: Lane L.

description: A good place to get work done. I wouldn't go here with friends as it's not an place to have lively conversations. Coffee is good but the music does get on my nerves so I always take headphones.
author: Liz M.

description:
very interesting ambiance! 
this place is mainly coffee and baked goods, and walls have non painted wood lining it making it look very sleek and modern. really nice, quiet, and relaxing atmosphere! 

the coffee is not bad.. i think they should keep a lid on the sugar and other add ons because there were some fruit flies around. but overall, its a really nice place. everyone and their mamas are on apple computers inside! nice lol.
author: Jessica C.

description: Chill place serving Ritual coffee.
author: Greg T.

description:
I come here in the day for pretty much for the same reason as 90% of the people you'll see here -- to work. Laptops galore, but in that respect it is a pretty great find. Mostly the same coffee drinks you'll find at Ritual Roasters on Valencia, with maybe half the hipster vibe. Granted, you're still in the Mission, but the minimalist decor and its location make it less trafficked, although on a busy work day you might be hard-pressed to find a table to work on.

My friend thinks the chairs are uncomfortable, but I'm fine with them -- they keep my back mostly upright, and I get my work done. There are plenty of outlets to plug into, and both small and larger tables for individuals or groups. The music is typical Mission hipster -- I've heard Beatles, Brian Eno, Tom Waits, some shoegazing. It's stuff I'd probably be listening to at home if I weren't listening to NPR. The music can be a little loud sometimes, but the noise level in general is pretty amenable to working -- some low-key conversations, but mostly people conversing with their computers. Although my friend played chess with his buddies here just the other day.

Parking is pretty reasonable if you don't live in the neighborhood -- you can usually find a spot on Folsom or Harrison, one or two blocks away (barring street cleaning, meters, some hour-long time limits). And, it's down the street from Humphry Slocombe and Dynamo Donuts, which is always a plus.
author: Robin L.

description:
Good coffee, limited food selection, good music, lots of outlets, free wifi, and a great patio out back. 

Great place to study and have a cup of coffee.  Lots of people working quietly on their laptops.
author: John E.

description: I could not have asked for a more perfect Sunday work session. Reading on a comfy couch, with a sweet little puppy nuzzled up next to me, and a giant window to the ivy-covered patio behind me--pretty much exactly like working from home, but with more peer pressure to stay focused.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Haus has all the attributes of a coffeehouse that I consider essential:
1. Good coffee- Ritual is awesome, they make good drip and espresso stuff.
2. Free WiFi- strong signal but lots of people with their noses in laptops (I don't have a problem with this)
3. Outdoor area- if Zeitgeist were a (toned-down) coffee shop.  Bonus points for loud top 40 music emanating from apartment next door
4. Clean bathrooms- speaks for itself.
A surprisingly well-appointed little shop on 24th I wholeheartedly recommend.
author: Eric S.

description: Fantastic place to go when everywhere else is packed. The seating is lovely and simple so there is no room for distraction. I always get a macchiato and work for a few hours. It's QUIET! I highly recommend this as a study spot. Parking is not all that terrible and it's in a cool neighborhood.
author: Jamie M.

description:
They get four stars for the food and coffee. I took away the other star because the furniture is not comfortable and there are not a lot of outlets if you want to stay there for awhile without having to compete for them. 

The food, however, is definitely a cut above what you'll get at other cafes - from the cinnamon bun to the vegan cookies. I would go here for a treat over Philz any day. I forget who makes their pastries, but I think it's an individual person, as opposed to a bakery, and I support that all the way.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
All hail the coffee shop that provides:

*  Free wi-fi with decent bandwidth
*  Quiet working space without annoying music
*  Cheap and well-made espresso drinks
*  Accessibility to public transit

Haus would only be better if some modern day Allen Ginsberg read his Howl here; maybe it would be titled "Retweet" instead of Howl because, well, that's the world we live in, but ...

Anyway.  Not enough coffee shops that make sitting there an entire day worthwhile, working with a steady stream of reasonably priced caffeine...
author: J W.

description:
I was down on blue bottle for their harsh decor, yet i love Haus's decor. Somehow they were able to take that bauhausian aesthetic and turn it into something cozy and comfortable. It's almost... oxymoronic: comfy bauhaus decor. 

This is one of the only places I get drip coffee in lieu of lattes because their drip coffee is french pressed and freaking delicious without fail.

They are also laptop friendly w/free wifi  AND outlets! Yay!
author: Sasha W.

description: Love the coffee, but hate the rude service.  I have been going there for months after I moved to the neighborhood but will never again.  Don't feel like going into full depth with the story...but trust me, the customer service is the worst!
author: Sasha Y.

description:
I like the simple decor and the fact that people are here to read/work and not chat. 

Occasionally, you will get some people talking about b.s. really loud.

The plus is when the male barista is working. The tall Mediterranean looking gentleman always brings a sparkle in my eye, when I order a coffee from him. 

Refreshing that he's down-to-earth and nice.
author: Faith W.

description: I go to Haus when I need to get some work done and really concentrate.  The coffee isn't really that good.  The loose-leaf herbal tea is great and they give you a whole pot!  Sometimes the music  is kind of weird and distracting.  I always bring my own music and ear buds just in case though.  It seems like sometimes people go there to have a chat, why?!?  Can't they see EVERYONE else is working?
author: Schuyler D.

description: WTF is up with the music here? Obnoxiously loud and weird.
author: Inigo M.

description:
PROS (there are many)
* Solid pine tables (not sticky)
* Fast internet: http://is.gd/7bo6c (13 down, 7 up). 802.11N!
* All shots are double with Ritual Roast beans. Ground the moment you ask for it. 
* Plenty of power plugs. 
* Fireplace in back
* Loads of Outdoor seating
* Baristas pick the music. All have great taste. 

CONS
* Furniture is rather HARD on the hiney, but it makes for an industrious visit if work is on your mind. 

I work from home/coffeelands and this is my go to spot. (and Sugarlump: http://www.yelp.com/biz/sugarlump-coffee-lounge-san-francisco
author: daniel m.

description:
Cool cafe with lots of airy open space.  

The barista grinds the coffee beans as you order, so no aroma is ever escaped.  Very smooth cup of joe.  They have just the simple stuff on the menu, Americano, latte, macchiato, no specialty drink.  Good coffee made simple.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
clean interior with lots of sunlight. it's one of the warmer day spots for work in winter especially if you snag one of the street-facing window seats. i like the no-nonsense tables and outlets that are perfect for laptop work. i have a hard time with life if it's both cold and dark. Haus's lighting alleviates wintertime SF for me. the back patio must be sweet during SF's warmer months but haven't had a chance to experience that yet.

the ambience is fairly austere and quiet, more of a low-key, steady flow. i can concentrate really well here but i can also see myself dozing off if i am not careful. the seating is set up to fight that temptation. too bad because dozing off for a 20 min. nap with that cozy lighting sounds wonderful. i can see the back patio being the right setting for that activity.

the coffee is good - San Fran beans from Ritual. dark, full bodied, bitter. it's not my preference, but it is legit. service tends to reflect the quiet austerity of the setting but i usually hit this spot after morning rush. i've never spilled a drink on to my laptop by placing it on the serving counter before. i am watchful and proactive about this because my laptop is very valuable to me, both as a tool and as the thing that contains my work.

i love this place. its quiet settles over me like a cloak, i get a lot of work done, and i get a consistent return of value whenever i come by.
author: ZP W.

description:
update: I'd say 3.5 stars. friendly service. bright and quite roomy, wood square tables and chairs, though at current state=wood and concrete, may not endear itself to the Stbux crowd. though it's too far into the Mission for a suburbanite, its newness, the patio area and sofas will bring me back.

Just opened. Will need to move it to the top of my to-try list:
Fireplace, check.
Sofas at said fireplace, check.
Patio, check.
Ritual Roasters beans espresso, check.
Noe Valley Bakery's items, check.
author: Peter L.

description:
I have to agree with another reviewer.  My favorite part is the vibe and music. The coffee is just ok for me.  

Please note that the music isn't very loud or obtrusive since they play downbeat or chillout music which means you can still study or work with it on.
author: Jay A.

description:
I've probably come here an average of one per week over the last 9 months. I definitely go a month without, and then go three times in one week. Regardless, I feel like I've been here enough times to have a really good say. 

Pros: 
- It is a breath of fresh air on busy, loud, culturally-diverse 24th Street. At the right time, it can be downright soothing by comparison. 
- The management seems to have listened. The music still trends to the quiet electronic, but the volume is lower. Loud enough to be white noise when you don't have headphones, but easy to cover with your own music. 
- POWER OUTLETS. Bless them. I wish every coffeeshop in San Francisco had such an abundance of power outlets. 
- They don't give you attitude if you order one coffee and then stay for four hours. 
- The coffee is really good, I think. OK, it's no Four Barrel, though I think they use their beans. I even think Dynamo Doughnuts down the way does a killer latte. But it's darned good coffee, and none of those other places have wifi. 
- The tea is a great deal, especially when you consider The Summit on Valencia. I think it's $2.50, and they'll refill the water as many times as you want (though the tea really can only handle it once). 
- From an aesthetic standpoint, the interior is restful. Very Ikea-ish, mid-century modern. Well-lit. Lots of tables for laptops. 

Cons: 
- Service is variable. The nice hipster dude seems to recognize me and does a great job. Consequently, he gets a tip. Some of the other baristas (just noticed that they're women) can cop an attitude. Yes, it's rude to carry on a conversation with a friend while a customer is waiting to order. If I go sit down while you make my coffee, that does not give you a license to make it 20 minutes later. 
- The chairs are hard as f***. Perhaps this is their don't-stay-forever tactic. But wait until one of the chairs or couch spots opens up, and problems solved. 
- Not enough outlets on the patio.
- The baked goods are blah.

But still, Haus is my solid go-to coffee shop in the MIssion.
author: Tom P.

description: Ok coffee, nice staff. However I had a horrible experience, a bad safety incident.  A solid piece of wood simply detached off a door, right onto my arm while I entered the backyard, missing my head by a few inches, it had four nails pointing out!!! The injury affected my hand and Its affecting me immensely. The staff member I talked to is in complete denial, despite the two witnesses who saw everything.  Now My hand is in constant pain, I'm taking pain medication, I can't bike, I have a super hard time dealing with the everyday life activities like cooking etc, I'm a piano player.... Can you imaginee how frustrating?? All I asked was for them to take resposibility and reimburse all my health care expenses caused by their absurd negligence. Apparently their lawyer told them to deny it all... Its very sad. So watch out you all!
author: Paul S.

description: This place needs to get out of the 3-3.5 star zone and into the 4-4.5 zone.  I love it.  First off, the barista was great. Some places will look at you like a rube if you don't ask about their Guatemalan blend's carbon footprint and buy a vegan brownie.  This place was great - fancy coffee (way over my head) but an easy vibe.  The main reason I'm coming out of my yelp-reader to yelp-reviewer shell for Haus is that its one of the few places in the city that WANTS you to come and get some work done.  Granted, if you're looking for macchiatos and crepes on a Sunday morning this is not for you.  But where I'm from "coffee shop" means a satellite library with good coffee and great people watching.  Its like, 'I have catch up with work stuff on a Saturday but I might as well do it listening to Broken Bells stealing glances at a girl checking email across the table and drinking a shot of espresso for every ironic mustache."  And that's Haus.  Reliable internet, good looking hipsters and open seats in a slick decor.  Get your productivity on.
author: Jeff M.

description: The barista here was rather unkind and uppity, just the sort you'd be expecting to work at one of these post-apocalyptic post-industrial post-any-opportunity-to-recognize-their-complicity-in-gentrification cafés. The folks outside, all programming folks, were having loud conversations about their weekend trips to Tokyo to shop and about where the coffee trends are happening in the Global South. I think my coffee and food tasted good, so there's that. And the outside is pretty.
author: Zac R.

description: This place was pretty spectacular.  Cute barrista, ritual roasters coffee, clean and quiet space.  Excellent pulled espresso, one of those places that's pretty much perfect everytime.   Think blue bottle, ritual, and four barrel...
author: Sean S.

description:
Was meaning to try De La Paz coffee, but didn't realize they use Ritual espresso. 

When I asked the barista if they do iced espresso drinks, he replied, "Um, I can...." which should have been my first warning sign. Nonetheless, I ordered an iced mocha anyway, and it was way over-iced, causing it to be watery. Ritual has mastered the perfect ratio, they need to learn from them.

Regardless, it's still great coffee and great baked goods (forget the name of the baker), so four stars for great sourcing (which is half the battle).
author: Mark A.

description:
Walked in here mid-morning on a Sunday.  We ordered a soy cap and a latte.  The coffee was ok.  Not the best cap I've had, but it was ok.  They didn't have many pastries to choose from either.

The venue is bright and spacious.  Looks like they're still working on a few things.  

I'll come back after they get their bearings but I won't be rushing back anytime soon.
author: Delilah B.

description:
They're still decorating at this point, but I hope the finial plan has some more personality.  Right now, the space is light and airy yet comfortable, but blank.  Some say blank is a look, I think its just unfinished!  Some big graphic foil letters in the square windows would make a nice sign, as would some plants and art up there and some color on any part of the wall.

I was surprised they didn't install multiple outlets along the custom bench, would have made sense for a computer crazy hipster San Francisco customer base. . . 

Coffee is acceptable and reasonably priced.  Looking forward to the backyard when it is completed.

I like the music selection too.

- - -
02/23/11

Turns out, they really were finished decorating!  BORING... I'd almost rather sit in a cubicle, almost.
author: Peter v.

description: Good but very pricy coffee (2 bevys, one of which was regular coffee, totaled nearly $10). I liked the vibe and space but the chairs are horribly uncomfortable. Not a place I'd spend a lot of time. I've never been back despite the hip factor.
author: lisa w.

description: I'm a regular here - the coffee is great, so is the place, but the music can sometimes be loud and haunting.
author: Pvy V.

description:
This used to be a cool spot to hangout, but I've since changed my mind. What's up with the plated wall covers over the electrical outlets? Unless you arrive with a charged battery, then forget getting any office work done here. 

The barrista's, although cute to look at, come with a bit of attitude. As if they are doing YOU a favor by serving you coffee. Did they forget that I just paid $3.50 for a dinky ass cup of latte? Or are they also doing me a favor by letting me use their dirty, unkempt bathrooms. Oh I know, it's because I get to sit at the unoccupied tables scattered with dirty dishes. 

Save yourself the trip, definitely don't go for the Internet. If you want to see hip-cool, fashion forward Mission neighborhood kids, great for the eye-candy, gossip front. If you want a decent cup of Jo with a smile, keep walking.
author: Sparkles D.

description:
Great cafe to work in. Wide-open internet, plugs for laptop juice, eclectic music selection, patio out back, and really good coffee and espresso drinks. 

The bathroom is kind of dirty, and almost all of the chairs have wooden seats which get uncomfortable after awhile.

Of course, Philz across the street has the best coffee in the Bay Area (West Coast?, USA?, planet Earth?), but it's pricey, and it's impossible to work there, which makes Haus a lovely addition to 24th Street.
author: Adam Z.

description: Ok, the tattooed girl got some new music (FINALLY), which is really good.  I also upgrade her from pretty cool to cool.  Haus keeps its 5 stars.
author: Six B.

description:
I don't really drink coffee so I can't really comment on their coffee selection. I just came here to do some work on my laptop.

GOOD:
- FREE WiFi! (no limit)
- Plenty of extension cords to charge your laptop!
- Usually there are several open seats unlike other places with free WiFi (*ahem* Coffee Bar).
- Lots of natural light so the place is pretty well lit.
- Place is clean and not super cramped.
- Drink prices are fairly reasonable. No $5+ Starbucks pricing here.

BAD:
- The seats are solid wood (not ergonomic) and aren't the most comfortable to sit on.

CONCLUSION:
Haus is a great place to get some work done on your laptop because they have FREE unlimited WiFi and plenty of charger outlets. It usually is not super crowded either. Like any other cafe, I wouldn't recommend studying here because it isn't quiet like a library.
author: Alex P.

description:
If this place goes under new management, it has the potential to be fantastic.  The space is wonderful and the outdoor patio is fantastic.  I can't picture myself giving this place another shot in the next year or so because of the ambiance.
1) The Barista encompasses everything bad and nothing good of hipster culture.  Serious attitude and acted like he was too cool to be there.  Am I an A-hole for tearing him away from Facebook to order a coffee?
2) The gorgeous outdoor patio was basically owned by the loud-talking CEO of some crappy start-up.  He carried on multiple conversations about potential meetings, investors, data, etc on his bluetooth.  This went on for about 30 minutes.  
3) The music is way too loud.
4) The coffee is over-priced.
author: pauline e.

description: Ah, Haus, you bring me back to the good ol' days in woodshop class. I'm really into the way you carved yourself a niche as a chill, work cafe where I can just sit down, plug in my laptop and easily type my whole day away. You're like a hipper version of a college library where I can always find a seat and immediately get into the zone since everyone else is also in deep concentration. The coffee is strong but the rasta music on repeat is getting tiresome, man.
author: Natalie T.

description:
3.5 stars. Will come back for espresso if I'm in this area (usually I'm around 16th/Mission so I go to Four Barrel).

Love the clean, bare decor. Espresso is tasty. Trendy, even when we were the first customers at 7:30am on a Monday.
author: Angela H.

description:
Haus' atmosphere is really good for getting work done, and I love that it's a laptop coffee shop.  The back patio is beautiful, though there were loud people smoking when I was there and Haus isn't dog-friendly. :(

The chai was pretty meh, and the food selection is abysmal.
author: Tony G.

description:
To the Lovely Owner of Haus: 

Please, for the love of God, help make your lovely coffee shop tolerable by regulating the music. 

I mean, it's always nice to visit a cafe of humans, where the baristas play their own music and create a unique atmosphere. It's not Starbucks, in other words, with the Norah Jones oeuvre on a loop (and they're for sale at the register where you purchase your sugar-free creme de menthe skinny frap!)

But there's a limit. Metal, Krautrock and experimental electronic music are off-putting to most. If it were just me I'd hold my tongue. Your cafe should be for the baristas more than it should be for me as an individual. But many others have discussed this in hushed tones and knowing glances. Nobody says anything because all the baristas are so great. Nobody wants to hurt anyone's feelings.

So this is just a friendly plea. From one customer. It doesn't have to be all Michael Bolton and Kenny G--lord knows that would be a different level of hell--but music that isn't so jarring would create a less anxious and jagged environment. 

Pleafully, 
A Customer

And this from another customer--a bit more specific:

Dear tall musician barista, 

After many non-euphonious hours spent at Haus I must sadly admit that while I still like lots of music, there is a genre, heretofore unknown to me, that is pure sonic misery. Perhaps it is your own music, self-recorded, and if that is true I apologize for being mean. But I suspect you are playing this genre of unlistenable weirdness (I think of it as "tech-not!") to impress a captive coffee shop audience with your avant-gardiness. As an old friend once said to me of an unusual fragrance I was proudly wearing: That is not perfume -- it is repellent!" 

Kindly, 
a patron
author: Charles D.

description: 20mbit symmetric comcast business wifi + nice coding environment
author: Todd T.

description:
Nice little spot. Pleasant, comfortable interior; nice courtyard out back. Over all a good find. (A note to my fellow laptop nomads: Free internet--and sockets.)

The coffee's fine here, but not great. They use Ritual beans, but the difference in the quality between Ritual's coffee and Haus's does, I'm afraid, go to show how much lies with the barista...
author: Michael S.

description: Usually I wouldn't patronize a faux bougie gentrifying business like this, but one day, I was exhausted, desperate for coffee, so I walked in. There was no one in line, just me...I was trying to figure out what I was going to order and the cooler-than-thou barista said something like, "are you going to take all day?" or some BS. I actually didn't hear her 100% (gutless hipsters do this mumbling thing..) so I said, "Wait...what did you just say to me?"  She just looked at me blankly so I asked her again. I would never buy anything here ever. If their 10.74 an hour employees act this lame, I can't imagine what the owner is like....
author: Walter P.

description: I stumbled in here after passing up on a long line at Philz coffee. The ambience of Haus can best be described as the apple store without the positive attitudes. Every single person was on the latest Macbook and upset that we were entering their workspace. The man who took my order seemed indifferent and slow. He was confused by my order of "a small coffee." It is still a mystery whether the woman behind the counter was an employee of this establishment. But one thing is certain, I would have needed the medication that she was clearly on, in order to recover from the flavors that came from the first sip. When I asked if my coffee was made with a French press, she looked at me with a lifeless expression and walked away. Their Americano tasted bitter, stale and unapologetic. The vanilla late tasted earthy-like hot bong water. I am convinced that the "small coffee" was actually water with brown food coloring. Save yourself the trauma of being treated like an unwanted houseguest and go anywhere else to get a real cup of coffee.
author: Miss N.

description:
Inarguably good espresso.  De La Paz knows what's up, and it's delivered by bicycle, which is a nice trivia tidbit.  

On a nice day, the back patio is a 'hidden gem', as the guides like to call them.  

Otherwise it feels like you're in a quiet dot-com office in Finland.  No decor to speak of, blond wood, white paint, exposed beams.  Service can be insanely slow if there is someone ahead of you in line, but never rude.  A good spot to stop by, do some emailing, get a jolt, and move on.
author: Arlo J.

description: I feel terribly having to knock down my once favorite place in the entire city!  But recently my experiences have all been lackluster or outright terrible (and I am a regular patron).   Haus is becoming more successful and popular but ironically that is making the atmosphere inside absolutely impossible.   The lack of seating, the one barista on bar who cannot humanly keep up with the volume, and lots of people especially groups who sit around and don't order, it all adds up to a sad face experience.  While Haus still has the most brilliant sunlight, its just become too stressful a place to be whether that be work on the mac or chat with a friend.   I'll certainly try to patron it again, but only during off-hours or very early mornings as to avoid the afternoon techie startup groups.  While seating is the main issue, I think they could do well for now to have a second barista on bar to handle the load.
author: Eric J.

description:
Really, this is two reviews in one: I would give 4 stars if I was judging purely on the coffee shop, but I also got beans there and they were nothing short of disappointing.  The coffee shop itself is great - the atmosphere is pleasant, not too stuffy - a good place to hang out with a book or a friend.  The latte was pretty decent as well - a little short of a 5 star rating, but still beats waiting in line for 15 minutes to get a latte at Ritual.  

Now, the beans.  Having enjoyed the overall Haus experience, I decided to get beans from them - I got De La Paz Bolivia Ciapec blend.  These beans are tasteless.  Really, they are NOTHING close to the French press coffee I tried there.  I am using almost twice the amount I ordinarily do, and the coffee still tastes like flavored water.  I am never again getting beans there.
author: N. S.

description: A simply designed local coffee house located a little bit off the beaten path of Mission Ave. Their solid edibles are nothing to write home about but their green tea selection is top notch. In the back patio one can enjoy a pleasant atmosphere when the weather is not too cold or damp.
author: Hubert H.

description:
I walked in and there were several people clad in plaid chatting at the counter. Probably complaining about how hard it is to bike up hills when your bike doesn't have gears. 

So I'm a hater. But after spending several hours here I really grew to enjoy the vibe. It's a great place to work with big tables and good lighting. The seats are all rather painful, but it keeps me awake. There's a set of leather chairs/couch as well, and lots of power outlets.

Cafe internet is known for being crappy and slow. Not here! I was doing some coding here and really appreciated that. 

They don't dick around with their coffee. Between the caffeine and painful chairs I was wide awake the whole time. 

The only real complaint I have is the music. For the most part I liked what they put on, but then about once an hour they decide to blast some metal. To each their own. Bring headphones.
author: Victor L.

description: Best wifi I have found and its going up to like 15 Mbps. Power for charging. Open spaces. Limeade
author: Frank G.

description:
Plain and Simple.     
Roomy and Sterile Environment.   
PATIO...I love patio on hot days!

The coffee list is short and simple, therefore even slowpokes won't generate a line.

Need to double check...I think they have 2 wireless signals running...
They are running strong and consistant.
I hate coffee shops with unreliable wi-fi...not this place.

Place is so cleaning it would put a computer chip clean room to shame!

They do need more tables inside and the patio to accomadate the busier periods.

Nice and well lit  slight industrial setting.

Go a simple patio...huge potential if they have volunteer spruce up the patio. Need to water the exisiting plants. Add some simple weatherproof electrical outlets and more table settings.

Place is now one of my favorite. Patio have a huge potential...could make this place sticks out on the grapevine and articles in the future...With carefull thinking and they don't need to put cheap upgrades like...outdoor christmas lights strung across with cheap solar system...get some free help from large pool of creative brain pool in the neigborhoold...donated potted plants...
author: S.K. Y.

description: Ok, I still love haus, but Jeebus, the music is really way too loud. Please, dear hipster dude behind the counter, please, lower the damn volume. You're running a business, i.e. it doesn't matter what you want to listen to (or how) - what matters is to make your clients are happy. Or maybe just not super extra pissed.
author: Fred A.

description:
Opened less than a week - a brand spanking new location of Ritual Coffee - no signs out front, just the Ritual Coffee logo by the window.  The inside feels like a just-put -together wood working 101 class.  Open backyard in the back.

Delicious coffee as always.
author: Hanson L.

description: Have been twice now, first on a weekday and then on Sunday. The baked goods are delicious - true French-style croissants and the cauliflower and butternut squash tart made a great lunch. Fast, reliable wifi, and abundant outlets. On the Thursday I visited, it was so quiet and people were so obviously studying that I felt bad chatting with the person I'd come to meet... but it also made it an amazing place to get work done. Sunday is a bit more buzzing but not too crowded.
author: Gillian M.

description: All the coffee at Haus is De La Paz, and is brewed using a french press, the espresso is usually from Ritual Coffee roasters..... thats all you need to know.  Yes, it is not a place for social butterflies to spread their wings, but it is a place to drink delicious no B.S. coffee.  When I first moved to the neighborhood I would frequent philz, but upon trying Haus i found their coffee a step above, while being two steps lower in cost.  A cup of coffee at philz costs $3.50, I am currently enjoying a delicious Americano from Haus for $2.... do the math.  I'm not dissing Philz, they make a good cup of joe, but I prefer the taste and cost of a cup from  DA HAUS.
author: Russell M.

description:
I judge coffee shops on 3 metrics: 1) ambience 2) taste of the coffee 3) service. Haus makes 4 stars on ambience, being docked the fifth star because the music is awful and too loud. The decor is modern and perfect for those of us who always have our Macbook (plenty of outlets, wide wooden tables).

The taste of my soy cappuccino was basically fine but not at par with Piccino, for example, to which I give 5 stars. 

The service was just fine. I definitely plan to come back here.
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
my friend and i needed a place to meet so we could plan our co-birthday party aboard the mexican party bus (review to come soon), so i suggested haus because i had been meaning to try it out. 

when i walked into the coffeehouse, i felt as if i had been dropped into a well-lit fishbowl of post-modern urban chic straight from the pages of dwell magazine. i like dwell magazine, so that was fine by me, but the place was so quiet that i started to feel a little unsettled. 

i picked up my phone to tell my friend that i had arrived early and a dozen heads turned to look at me. 

the room was filled with tables that could hold at least two laptops, and it seemed that every single person in the room was making exceedingly productive use of a table. it felt odd to be planning a party in that quiet room amid the intense, hard-working freelancers that packed the place.

haus does not serve the kind of coffee that would make your anti-coffee mother fall in love with lattes (blue bottle coffee) or give you a reason to wake up at 10 am on a saturday to bake 130 cupcakes with your friends (philz). 

however, the baristas  know how to make a pretty design in your foam, and now i know enough to bring my mac book pro the next time i am here.
author: annie l.

description: Nice coffee, nice atmosphere, but really bad customer service.  I ordered an extra dry cappuccino and it came out like a wet latte - with barely any foam and very wet foam.  I asked the barrista, Lisa, if she could remake it for me extra dry and she told me that she makes cappuccinos wet.  She said she could remake it but couldn't promise that I'd be happy because I'm 'so picky.' I said that I'd like her try and said that I'd like at least 1/3 foam.  She argued with me for a long time, and it seemed like she just didn't want to even try to make a dry cappuccino. Then, she finally told me she would give me my money back and wasn't going to remake the cappuccino for me because I was too picky.  In retrospect I think she might just never have been trained about how to use the foam maker properly and got very defensive when I asked her to do something that she didn't know anything about.
author: C. Athena A.

description: Oo those little banana nut muffins maybe small, but perfectly moist with crispy sugar topping, I'd swear they were home made. Oh yeah, and their coffee is quite good .
author: Suzy M.

description: Haus is a very refreshing spot, with big windows in front, a leather couch and chair in back, OUTLETs!, and an ample outdoor seating area on the back patio. Windows are large and there is plenty of natural light. The coffee is from Ritual, and will make your hair stand up. The pastries are unique, fresh, and tasty. The barista was really sweet and friendy, even after I crashed a plate to pieces on the concrete floor. The crowd was very chic and friendly, and the music did not grate on my nerves.
author: Chris W.

description: I want to retract my earlier surlier review and let y'all know that not only have I never seen the tardy employee again, but that everyone else who works at Haus is awesome.  They are always friendly, always into chatting about coffee, and all make a mean espresso drink.  I have taken to buying my weekly beans from here- lovin' the La Paz!  Finally a SF roaster that roasts for the bean, not the brand (yes I am referring to the tea that Ritual and Four Barrel try to pass off as coffee).
author: Kirsten H.

description: Ducked in here trying to avoid humphrey slocomb. Good coffee, kinda weird vibe tonight tho. Spartan atmosphere and every single person clacking away on a device. Blank walls and floors looking not too inviting.
author: Maria R.

description: OH my god blissful ambiance and music. I was looking for someplace new to do some work and I stepped in here, very pleasantly surprised by the vibe. Coffee is...meh. Mocha too sweet. And oh my god super lame aloof pissy lady at the counter. She clearly hates this job or having a job. I can relate, but I hope she's not here next time I come.
author: Evan S.

description: Wow!  What a difference a half a year (and a different barista) makes!  One of the smoothest lattes I've had.  Decor is the same -- meaning Zen-like minimalism.  Very clean lines: beautiful, bare oak (I think ;-) and white walls.  If you want a clean space to think in/get stuff done, this is it!
author: Ari M.

description:
Opening a coffee shop across the street from Philz takes balls, given it's status as a local favorite that can do no wrong.  But really, the two are a bit like apples and oranges, and Haus has stepped in to fill a void on 24th street that Philz cannot satisfy.  That void is the espresso drink void.
Haus serves a full list of coffee drinks - espresso, cappuccino, latte, macchiato - as well as french press coffee made fresh every 20 minutes.  That french press is really what's up, it's so dense and flavorful you'll never want drip again.  The espresso is made by Ritual and the coffee beans are from De La Paz, both local companies.  The baristas here really care about the quality of the drink and really want the customer to be satisfied with every detail - be it the foam on your cappuccino or the volume level of the music.
They do charge extra for soy (50cents), and are experimenting with other non-dairy options such as almond milk.  The pastries are also made by young, new, mission district bakeries and the choices are more interesting than your typical banana bread and a bagel.  There's sea salt & lavender cookies, cheese scones, vegan apricot scones, vegan cookies and vegan breakfast bars.  
The space is uuuuber modern and raw, which you should have guessed given the name "Haus."  I think a few more decorative objects might help - simply because the surfaces do little to absorb noise, making it very tinny and echo-y in there.  Perhaps some velvet paintings from TJ guys?? j/k.  There's also a large back patio with some tables, making it perfect on sunny days or for those of you who love a cigarette with your coffee.  Just try not to take a gnarly deuce in the bathroom if you choose to go that route.
author: Katherine K.

description: This place is kinda of amazing. Great french press coffee and great location. I am enjoying it a bit better than other over crowded coffee shops in the same vicinity. The staff is super knowledgeable about the coffee, its origins and roasting procedures.
author: Luis G.

description:
good espresso (ritual)
good wifi
good outlet situation
good patio
good sturdy chairs. well, they are good for work, not if you want to sit comfortably and chat.
in terms of atmosphere - at the front it has a warehouse feel, at the middle, it has a hair salon feel (seriously, massage music and all. well, actually, that's throughout the place. i'll definitely rethink the music) and all the way inside, at the patio, it has a mission st. feel. 
wish the barista was nicer though - that would probably have made me more enthusiastic about this place.
author: tal n.

description:
My primary reason for visiting Haus today was to get out of my apartment and work remotely and to do it one of SF's cool coffee shop hangs.  
I arrive at 2:30 and there are no tables available. I eye some couches in the back and figure I'll park myself there until one becomes available.
I am barely acknowledged by the young staff member behind the counter  Ouch!  First minute = 1 star.
I order a Cappuccino & a cookie (beware, eat somewhere else before coming here if planning on doing an afternoon's worth of work - there is only a very sparse selection of baked goods).  
Lucky for me, a table frees up just as I pay.  Perfect timing!

Cookie is yummy.  Cappuccino is good, not great. = 3 stars $5.00 pays for both.

Shucks!  Forgot my earphones.  Luckily, some VERY COOL ambient music comes on... I'm quickly warming up to this place and getting over my initial lack of being wowed by my drink. All patrons are here to work...  which for this afternoon, I appreciate.  There are no loud-volume talkers to have to filter out.

Note: Not all tables have access to power outlets.  
Unfortunately, I'm sitting at one of these. But luck is on my side again. With only 50 minutes battery power left, someone across the room departs and I snag up a table next to power source.  
At this time I order a Soy Chai. Boy behind counter smiles this time.  OK.  Maybe because it was so sunny out when i first walked in, he was not so happy to be working.  Now that is a little dark outside, his mood is brightening.  We'll bump customer service up to 3 stars now.
Again, the drink is sub-par... lacking that extra creamy something I expect my chai latte from a "cool" cafe to deliver.  At least it cost only $3.00 for the soy chai... a good $1-1.50 less than Starbucks would charge for the same!

So why 4 stars?

Despite not being too impressed with the strength of the drinks (I'll try the straight up coffee next time), I LOVE the light airy environment with the light wood tables, great overhead lighting, and super clean environment. The staff DID warm up (i award progress!), nice mixed crowd of people focusing on their work -  no pretentious customers!  And fabulous background music!

So, I will definitely be back and will order straight up coffee next time.
author: Amber W.

description: I like this place but not a huge fan of the location.  It's a nice and simple place - there's a patio in the back and the inside has a cute little couch and armchair setup amongst other surprisingly comfy tables.  Got the mocha - which I thought was pretty standard.  I'm mostly pleased with the environment; I could kill hours here.  But there's not much else around here and it's kind of a trek for me to venture out to this part of the mission.  If it were a bit more convenient, I'd definitely make it a regular chill spot.
author: Jessica W.

description:
If "life in the Outer Mission" was a category on Yelp, it would get an extra star with the addition of Haus.  The humble newcomer to artisan coffee in the Mission, Haus has only been open a month or so as of this writing.  There's a lot to discuss here, but let's start with the coffee.  Haus procures beans from two choice roasters, both within a few blocks of the cafe: De La Paz and Ritual Roasters.  For now, De La Paz is the bean of choice for their house coffee which is always french press and without a doubt the best french press I've had to date.  I can't even make it this good at home and I'm not sure what their secret is.  Espresso and espresso drinks are currently pulled with Ritual beans, and as you would expect, it's mighty fine.  I've only had espresso made by Ryan, one of the managers who is there in the mornings and have yet to try out the training of the rest of the staff.  Ryan certainly knows his stuff and is super friendly to boot.  Kudos to the management for offering customers a choice of local roasters.  I'd love to see what Jason and Co. over at De La Paz can put together for a Haus espresso blend.  
Unless I'm mistaken, this will be the first cafe in the mission with outdoor seating in the back.  There's a large patio nestled between some houses and ivy-covered walls that's not yet ready for customers, but looks to be soon.  I'm impressed that they seem to be building much of their own seating by hand.
For now the atmosphere has not fully developed, but this translates to short lines and plenty of available seating at their big and small tables, and their fireside sofa.  Let's get some local art in here and we'll be set!
author: Carlisle H.

description: Excellent coffee, not crowded, not overwhelmed by lousy music or pretentious art. And notably, instead of a stuck-up hipster barrista there is a very nice, helpful fellow named Ryan who handles both macchiatos and local aggressive drunks gracefully, doing just what's needed. I love the decor and the light and the back garden. A choice has been made to have not too many tables -- so when you walk in, you don't feel you've stumbled into someone else's library. Instead, there's room for you. Perfect wifi and electricity too.
author: V. J. L.

description:
love the fact that there is outdoor seating and i can have coffee in the sun. 

coffes is good but not my favorite.

however, i did try de la paz today and thought it was delicious. maybe because i was out in the sun or just it was really good or maybe both. i think it was the combination of both. maybe i will have to come here more often...
author: Rachna P.

description: A little stark and not as cozy as I like my coffee houses to be. I think they're going for modern, but the place almost looks unfinished interior design-wise. The menu is a bit limited too - probably 5 or 6 basic coffee drinks and some tea. So, yeah, this place definitely hits a minimalist vibe. I don't think they even have a sign out front. The coffee is good though, but get decaf if you don't want a caffeine headache for 2 days. That's strong stuff... or maybe it's just me. It was pretty quiet on a Thursday evening (like a lot of reviews have said, mostly single people on laptops), but that's good for quiet conversation... or laptop use. Service wasn't super friendly, but the guy got the coffee in the cup, so I can't be too critical. It's not a bad place, but I probably wouldn't go back.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Haus has Ritual coffee without the pretentiousness, and all the space of Four Barrel without the bat cave feel.  The whole place is bright and full of light, and the wood decor adds to the open welcoming feel.  The coffee is great, the service is friendly, and the wifi is free.  Woohoo!
author: Linda L.

description: Four stars for the stylin' minimalist interior and outdoor space.  I like Ritual coffee but these guys don't really do it justice so no points there.  Minus three stars for just about the most hostile and downright rude service I've ever experienced in San Francisco.
author: Joseph S.

description: Internet woes seem to be addressed, and Laura is AWESOME. Together it makes it a great experience :D
author: Vivek N.

description: As others have pointed out, the space is bright and inviting. Love the music - it's generally interesting without being too jarring. They seem to really care about the quality of their coffee and they brew an excellent french press. I prefer their coffee to Ritual's - not sure what they do differently, but it works. Overall a top notch place for a quiet conversation or a productive work day.
author: Anonymous F.

description: They are playing the Dark Knight score right now! This is why I love this place so much more than Philz: better music, better internet, and a back patio! Philz does have those delicious sambosas though, and nice couches, but Haus is definitely better for working.
author: Machinations F.

description: Definitely my favorite coffee shop in the mission. Good drinks, outlets, reliable wifi, and a fabulous back patio. Don't like the music? Put on headphones. I also really dig the "modern" look because, honestly, most coffee shop art is kind of awful. Friendly baristas and patrons---all- around great spot to get some work done.
author: camilla r.

description: i really wanted to love this place, i drove by it one day and it looked like it had open space, a lot of tables, and would be a great places to study. ended up meeting a friend there a couple days later to get some work done, but it was busy. had to spend the first hour cramped together in a small table. the food selection was pretty much next to nothing by the time we got there (only noon, so not THAT late) and overall the ambiance wasn't what i expected it to be. The coffee was nothing to write home about, and call me mainstream, but they didn't have splenda (nor any clean spoons available to mix sugar in my coffee)
author: Micki C.

description: Excellent coffee, even better music.  The tall, slighly shy/quiet barista with curly hair has amazing taste in electronic music.  It is worth coming here just to hear what he's playing.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I agree with Adam Z. This is a great, mellow place to sit down and work. Free WiFi, plenty of laptop plug in areas, and space to spread out. For the car-bound folks, there is unmetered, unrestricted parking over by Humphrey Slocombe on Harrison... so if you are heading over from another part of town, you don't have to worry about feeding a meter or getting a 2 hour parking violation ticket from DPT! :)

I can confirm it is wheelchair accessible- yesterday while I was there, some random guy came in in a wheelchair and tried to jack my keys, which was pretty crazy and unexpected... 

For the most part this place is tranquil and helps me focus on getting my work done! It ain't servin up the Philz level brew you can nab across the street, but Ritual roaster coffee ain't chopliver!

I occasionally splurge on the Banana Pecan bread or the Almond Croissant...but at 2.50 a pop, it is almost as much is the cup of coffee I get! 
Definitely recommended!
author: Erin C.

description: They're not quite up & running, but how excited am I? Wireless - this will be my new office. And I think I spied a patio in the back. Totally comfy and cool atmosphere. And, yes, there is Ritual Roasters coffee.
author: maureen f.

description: Your typical mission ~hip coffee house~ with a minimal 'ikea' interior that feels modern-cabinesque. This place was oddly extremely quiet, like more silent than a library and even more awkward. Everyone seemed zoned into their laptops, with no warmth radiating from anyone, only the slim ultra sleek fireplace. The coffee was ok, combined with the brown sugar, a little milk and some cinnamon it created a strange sweet acidic zesty flavor. I prefer Blue Bottle's flavor.
author: Cori W.

description: I love a good coffee, and this place can do something special with it's ritual roasters beans.  To top it off they have an awesome fireplace and leather couch combo and cool blond wood furniture.  Looking forward to the art to come through as well as the patio opening up.
author: Adrian L.

description: They're still working the kinks out, but head here now and get to know it. Despite the last stages of construction still going on, the coffee is great, the staff friendly and the space vibrant. I imagine great success, and that little stretch of Folsom needed a good place to get some coffee and hang out. Great addition to the neigborhood, congrats!
author: Mike L.

description:
pretty nice spot, good coffee/wifi/snacks.  outdoor space is pleasant on warm days.  

just bring your headphones because they play very loud, awful music.
author: E. R.

description: I enjoyed a delicious ice americano. Great outdoor patio. I appreciate the simple design of the space and use of basic materials.
author: Thanya S.

description:
Nice newcomer on 24th St. cafe scene.
Spare decor, but bright walls with warm wood. Excellent patio.
Needs artwork to make this feel lived in. Wifi and outlets.

Need to expand their drink menu to include diet cola, my other caffeine of choice. Pastries are fine but what about bagels, sandwiches? Hopefully coming as they get settled in.
author: John L.

description:
very clean and simple cafe around mission. one of the less hip cafe around, but i dont mind because i tend to like these type of cafe more.

4 stars--today was my first time so i wouldnt want to be overwhelmed with the place. i had a chai and it was prepacked. i dont mind but it was good. not a lot of choices for the drinks but you live with it. i did! LOL

the great thing about this cafe is the concrete backyard! aahhh.. very relaxing to just do you shizz out there, but i wish there would be outlets. not a bad first time! :) i shall bring my laptop next time, but probably not on the backyard! hmmmm...
author: Marc K.

description: Great place to get some work done. Really like their coffee and chai, love the back yard. SImple decor is nice. Lots of places to plug in as well.
author: cindy p.

description: This place needs a bigger menu but other than that I really liked the style of the place and the free wifi. just be careful now it gets super packed people there mostly for the wifi no more peace and quiet.
author: Jim L.

description: Haus is amazing. I might just deposit my check into their bank account if they served food.
author: Jess F.

description: Perfection.  Great staff, good coffee, beautiful room.  Vibe is warm and sunny.  What more do you need?  Great place to get work done.
author: Chris S.

description:
i love haus! while doing recon in SF, my dear friend E took me to haus several times for some quiet writing/thinking/job applying. it's sparse with just enough plugs for all the folks with laptops. the americano is just right; and the music in the background is just loud enough to be background noise without being a distraction. the simple wooden tables with chairs dotted across a simple space. nothing much to distract you if you need a good cup of coffee and space to work. E would go there for many hours to work. and knowing that's where she hunkered down is kind of a comforting image for me, now that i'm back in nyc. 

what i love even more about haus is when E texted me one day to say "i'm leaving haus and on my way home." heart...
author: Diana L.

description: This place deserves five stars...so why the four star rating? I was not a fan of the music. Scratch that, I HATED the music. Overly dramatic, the only good thing about it was there were no lyrics, so it didn't impede my studying too much. Otherwise, Haus is perfect! It's minimalist, functional, and no-nonsense but at the same time, very charming and warm. My friend and I both ordered teas, which actually woke me up. The little amount of caffeine in tea usually doesn't do much for me, but Haus tea did the trick! The one thing I really loved was that the cafe was super spacious and the tables were large, meaning there's room to spread out papers and books and laptops. Plus there were an abundance of outlets. Also, there's great big windows that capture all the sunlight, making this a very bright and great place to sit for a while. The one thing (other than the music) was the really cheap and crappy toilet paper...not a fan. Otherwise, I was loathe to leave this place. Best serious studying I've done in a long time. Will be back!
author: Jing P.

description: This place has really nice light and couches and a back patio. All good things. The coffee is pretty darn good, and even the limeade was delicious. Biggest drawback is that the baristas constantly talk about how amazing their own coffee is -- loudly enough to distract you from actually enjoying your coffee. A little less ego would go a long way at this place.
author: Lester D.

description: They have a small selection of drinks. I think the drinks are good but not great. The inside has a good amount of tables, but they all get full. Its also a bit warm on the inside, and a bit cold on the outside. In the back, courtyard area there's more tables. As others have said, its a relatively quiet cafe where most folks seem to be studying or chatting. Its very low key.  Wifi is alright.  They have outlets. The drinks are well priced, I like it. The parking around the area isn't too hard to get even during the weekday but its $2 per hour. BART is a short walk away. Lots of power outlets, even in the outside courtyard. I would give it 4 stars if I could get a nice table inside and if they had a bigger selection of drinks including iced drinks (like starbucks).
author: Dijon Y.

description: The coffee (both French press and espresso drinks) have been great each of the 15+ times I've ordered here. The baked items have all been  delicious. I like the music. I don't care that the employees are not super overtly friendly. Why would I need that? They have been perfectly happy to discuss the music with me when I've asked about it. Plus I always like a place with outdoor seating (which they have both in front and in back).
author: Jeremy E.

description: Nice atmosphere full of hipsters, but the barista was not too friendly and seemed annoyed that I didn't tip her on my $2 Americano. Sorry, maybe if you had been friendlier I'd have considered it.
author: Geoffrey U.

description: The coffee is fantastic. I found the environment incredibly conducive to getting work done. The employees were very nice, not snotty-pants like so many of the quality coffee places.
author: alli K.

description: Nice laid back vibe.  Not too crowded (yet), bright and sunny.  I love coming here to get some work done. Good coffee, at least some of which is from Ritual  Plenty of outlets (surge protected no less).  Seating isn't super comfy but it kinda helps with productivity.  Working on my dissertation proposal here right now!  Probably should get back to work.
author: Daniel S.

description: I like this place, but when I come in and the employees are playing loud thrash / noise metal at the expense of the people are trying to talk or work who keep shooting him dirty looks which he doesn't notice as he continues to read his graphic novel, they should pay more attention. Makes me less likely to come back.
author: Oded G.

description: A not inconsiderable portion of my (still brief) time living in San Francisco has been spent as un(der)employed member of the tech worker bourgeoisie. To provide a kind of shelter for such undercover pests to society there exist, naturally, copious amounts of coffee shops designed to house pseudodestitute freeloaders as efficiently as possible, and then attempt to make a profit from the slow trickle of purchases under $5 that they provide. In exchange for this meager but reliable natural resource, it is custom to provide amenities such as wireless in order for us creatures to perform strenuous labor while reposing in front of various computing devices. As many of the other reviews for Haus indicate, this space is in the upper tier of establishments of its kind. Pleasing Scandinavian decor, good coffee (I favor the $2 iced americano myself), comfortably designed space to actually sometimes do useful work in, a nice outdoor patio, a good density of clientele. Highly recommended, and I should know; I'm here right now as I write this, appearing to all external observers very hard at 'work.'
author: Peter B.

description: Wow, hands down the kind of service that makes you want to move out of San Francisco. Lady, if you do not like people you should not be working the counter. Rude and useless. After the crappy service, Miss Sunshine cut the line at the bathroom with a dismissive, 'I work here.' Not for long I hope. Someone else on this block must deserve my cash more than this place. Skip it.
author: K G.

description: Very cool space, great coffee, nice staff. What more do you need?
author: Shawn B.

description: this is one of my alternative coffee spots when the queue for philz is beyond my capacity for patience.  decent coffee, and equally decent prices.  i like the minimal decor, and the unfinished wood.  the bonus is the outdoor patio where you can enjoy your beverages.
author: Sheri N.

description: Good coffee (drip and espresso-based), good place to read/study/work.
author: Max D.

description: a great little coffee coffeeshop! its free from distractions and serves ritual coffee. the aesthetic is clean and the barista was really nice. there was also a nice jazz duo playing in the daytime.
author: Mark H.

description: The space is minimal and bright with big windows. comfy. great fireplace.  coffee and snacks superb. hip cute staff. nice owner. the back patio has so much potential...hope to see them do something with it. only complaint is the restroom needs to be cleaned more often.
author: Missy D.

description: i like the simplicity of this cafe.  good chai, found a place to sit and was able to focus on work.  however, could do without the loud, don't-even-know-how-to-describe-it-music -- wouldn't have bothered me if it just wasn't so loud, or if i had headphones on, but i was with a friend so didn't want to be rude...i had to shout over, "what???" several times across the table.
author: Christine B.
